The only way is up if Moyes moves on

David Moyes has been linked to Sunderland if Martin O’Neill leaves at the end of the season. Now why on earth would he want that? The frustration for Moyes is surely the glass ceiling that limits those clubs beneath the Champions League elite. He can only go so far at Everton. Yet if anything, as O’Neill is discovering, at Sunderland it is worse.



On the day O’Neill was appointed, it was stated that Sunderland’s ambition was to become a top 10 club. Instantly, it seemed limiting for a manager of his ability. Who cares who comes 10th — or ninth, eighth or seventh for that matter? The problem for Moyes is that he does good work, without glory. Unless there is a dramatic injection of funds — which is not allowed now anyway — what would be different at Sunderland?

Out of their league: There would be no sense in David Moyes (right) leaving Everton for Sunderland

The suggestion that Fernando Torres could be part of Chelsea’s deal for Radamel Falcao at the end of the season is a logical one.



Atletico Madrid is Torres’s spiritual home and he would be welcomed back like a hero, which his confidence needs. Chelsea, in turn, would get the goalscorer they require to rebuild for next season.

Everyone would be happy — and who thought that of Torres’s inevitable departure from Stamford Bridge?

Trading places? A deal seeing Radamel Falcao (left) and Fernando Torres (right) swapping sides is plausible



Dimitri Seluk, agent for Yaya Toure, attempted to bounce Manchester City into a hurried new deal for his player. It seems strange in these instances that the clubs do not respond by targeting the fractious middleman.



Why should they deal with Seluk after his outbursts?



If Toure wants a new deal at City, it could be politely explained that the only way it happens is if he finds a less outspoken representative.

Seluk would certainly be steering Toure away from Manchester City, if the club spoke about him in such extreme terms.

rank_150.title: MARTIN SAMUEL - THE DEBATE: West Ham saved the Olympic Stadium from the idiots who built it, no wonder Karren Brady is smiling
rank_150.text:
West Ham saved the Olympic Stadium from the idiots who built it, no wonder Karren has a big smile on her face



Should West Ham United have the Olympic Stadium? If not, what alternative is there beyond bulldozers.



The column that started this week’s barney is over there on the right.



The debate starts here.

.....................................................................................................................





Knock it down as it is becoming a sponge for corruption at the expense of the working class tax payer. Kido 44, Birmingham

I think you’ll find the working-class tax payer, the middle-class tax payers, indeed all tax payers have already paid for it. We can write it off as the most expensive summer ball in history, or try to get some of the money back, but over time. Also, I’d leave you to break the news of your grand post-Olympic plan to Jessica Ennis. 'Hi Jess, Kido here. Thanks for all the hard work and I thought I’d keep you in the picture about what is happening next. You know that stadium where you trained to win your gold medal, the one in Don Valley? Yes? Good. Well, we’re knocking it down. Yes, I thought you’d like that. And the other place, where you actually won your gold medal? Well, we’re knocking that down, too! Just in case you were wondering about legacy. Now, can I put you down for three tons of souvenir rubble? Lovely.'

Come on Boris, you're losing her. Say something funny, man....

That's better, we knew you had it in you, you silver-tongued devil you

Yes, the Olympic Stadium has to be used, but the taxpayer shouldn't be subsidising a wealthy Premier League club. It gives West Ham United an unfair advantage. Ferdinand, London

No more so than the compulsory purchase orders around Highbury and the Emirates Stadium that benefited Arsenal. Businesses were evicted so a football club could build flats. Tottenham Hotspur also cut a good deal with Haringey council. Big business often gets a break this way. The argument runs that building projects by football clubs are a source of local employment and of revenue for the area. Without doubt more money will come into Stratford with West Ham there, than if we knocked the site flat for houses or business parks that in the current economic climate would stay largely empty.

.....................................................................................................................

The unholy trinity of David Sullivan, Karren Brady and David Gold always want something for nothing. They are never happy. They are perpetually miserable. It is their default response. They achieved nothing at Birmingham City. Now they have a brand new stadium. It should be a cathedral of football for West Ham but their miserable, top of the shelf sleazy magazine mindset will turn it into the sporting equivalent of a £1 shop. Poor old Sam Allardyce is on borrowed time. His thanks for all of his hard work and effort will be the chop at the end of the season. A more interesting article would have explored all of Lord Coe's Pinocchio tales of Olympic legacy. It is time that he was held to account for his empty promises. Nearly one year on, it is the asset strippers who are reaping the rewards. Kismet1001, London

I don’t think the owners of West Ham are asset-stripping the stadium, or the club. The opposite, in fact, considering the level of personal investment required to prop it up after the Icelandic banking disaster. They all looked pretty happy in the photographs to me, too. And we can certainly see how Birmingham City have thrived in their absence. It is not West Ham’s fault that the idiots who oversaw the project made such poor preparation for its post Games legacy. With better planning they would have had the upper hand in negotiations and would be considering several viable suitors. As it was, West Ham had the only game worth playing and could drive a hard bargain. Some of us were pointing out the flaws in government thinking on the stadium close to 10 years ago. We were called cynics at the time and worse when the Games got underway. But it was always going to end in a desperate battle not to be left holding a very expensive baby, because the thinking was muddled from the beginning.

Show your colours: West Ham will move in to the Olympic Stadium - don't rule out more fireworks

Of the two, either West Ham or Leyton Orient, the only logical winner would have to be West Ham, but even then they are not going to fill the stadium unless it is a London derby or Manchester United are in town. I am split on whether they should leave Upton Park. From a financial point of view they should move, but compared to West Ham's spiritual home, the Olympic Stadium will be soulless and won't generate the same atmosphere, not even with 60,000. Teapot, North Herts

These are the shared concerns of every West Ham supporter and many have mixed feelings. Upton Park was always a fearsome place to go to, particularly under floodlights, and without doubt some of that edge will be lost. Having said this, perhaps the most ferocious atmosphere I have encountered in European football in recent years was at Napoli, where there is a running track and distance between the fans and the players. So it can be done.



.....................................................................................................................

Expensive to keep. In a filthy state. Knock it down and the state wouldn't have to spend any more money. Sell the land to a developer. Fatharry, Middlesbrough

To build what? There is not enough demand for houses in Stratford and the City has already moved to Canary Wharf.

A taste of things to come: How the Hammers will (kind of) look in their new home

Crowd pleaser: Usain Bolt was one of THE stars of the Olympic Games last summer

You say the stadium was a cock-up – so where exactly were we supposed to have the Olympics? The stadium needed to be built regardless of what then happened to it. Fmxguy, United Kingdom

It isn’t about whether the stadium was needed, it is about having the vision to build a stadium that had a future beyond last summer, without needing a complete refit.



.....................................................................................................................

West Ham's bid: a £500m stadium for dirt-cheap rent, remodelled with tax payers money. Tottenham Hotspur's bid: buy stadium outright, rebuild it as football stadium, remodel Crystal Palace athletics centre to state-of-the-art 25,000-seater stadium to fulfil Olympic legacy, all out of own pocket. Yes, West Ham clearly were the only option. Steve, Southampton

Except where were Tottenham last week, Steve? They got what they wanted out of their local council and stayed where they are rather than embark on a project that their fans despised and could have killed the club. By the end, West Ham were the only option. The one you cite did not exist.



.....................................................................................................................

Isn't it typical of this country that absolutely no thought went into what would happen to the stadium after the Olympics? It could and should have been designed so it could accommodate football and rugby without the now obvious necessity and expense of adapting to be fit for purpose. Sheer economic folly. But when one considers that Lord Coe, with an absurdly elitist view of athletics, and Ken Livingstone and Tessa Jowell were the main drivers behind it perhaps we shouldn't be surprised. Economics Rocks, Welwyn Garden City

Nearly a decade ago in a column in The Times I compared Coe’s attitude to that of opera subsidies versus popular musical theatre. In the end, the triumvirate you mention made such a monumental mess of it, we ended up with popular musical theatre, that the government had to subsidise as if it were opera. That takes some doing. And the newspaper in which that column appeared made Lord Coe its Man of the Year for 2012. Hey ho.



Take a good look: Because you never know, Upton Park could soon be gone

Presumably, when the West Ham owners sell Upton Park to property developers for many millions, all of the money will be given to the government? Or will it be trousered by Gold, Sullivan & Brady? I wonder. The reality is that West Ham have been handed a 54,000-seater stadium for little more than what they paid for a championship winger in the summer and as such have been given a massive financial boost just as the financial fair play rules begin. Royals Steve, Surrey

The Upton Park site is worth around £40m, so at least £15m of that will go to the government. It is a good deal for West Ham, I’m not denying that. But the only reason it has fallen this way is because the last government, in alliance with Lord Coe and then Mayor Ken Livingstone, made a monumental mess of the project from the outset. So the moans are rather misdirected. As far as FFP is concerned, ground improvements are not covered.

.....................................................................................................................

I agree that West Ham is a better option than no option, but I still think Tottenham's bid would have been better for the country. Although it involved removing the athletics track it would have turned it into a proper football stadium instead of this horrible mish-mash. Luke, Manchester

Yes, Luke, but part of London winning the right to host the Games was the pledge to leave a large capacity athletics arena. Only one football club's bid guaranteed that legacy.



.....................................................................................................................

So the West Ham fan thinks his club should be given a free stadium like Manchester City were. What a surprise. J2kenny, Liverpool

No, actually, the West Ham fan is ambivalent about it, like many other West Ham fans. The impartial journalist, however, recognises West Ham were the only game in town and opines accordingly. And, just for that little pop, the West Ham fan is going to play you his favourite version of I’m Forever Blowing Bubbles.



West Ham did not clean up the mess, they took advantage of the mess. I hope there is judicial review after judicial review until either West Ham pay for the full renovation, or they knock it down and build thousands of needed affordable homes on the site. The majority don't care that they got the stadium, most fans are laughing that they are moving there. But when a Premier League club is earning a minimum of £60m a year in television rights and get this kind of deal it is taking the mickey out of every hard working taxpayer. Couple that with the rumoured £200m West Ham are said to make from building flats on its current ground, I think you can understand that we feel totally shafted.

Stephen, London

That’s right, Stephen, because the government lawyers involved in judicial reviews work for free and with no charge to the taxpayer. West Ham will not pay for full renovation because it is not their problem. They wouldn’t buy a stadium with no roof, poor sight lines and an athletics track. Nobody would. They are tenants, so the onus was on the landlord to get the place straight first. If you are shown a flat to rent and water is pouring in through the ceiling, you would demand the true owner got that fixed before you signed the agreement, yes? It’s like that. This is why the government had to bend to make it work. And you think homes where Upton Park stand would fetch £200m? Halve it, then halve again – and it’s still too much. I don’t know what part of London you are from, Stephen, but I’m guessing not the east. There are pockets where property had boomed, but Stratford isn’t one of them.

.....................................................................................................................

You are totally wrong about West Ham clearing up the mess, they've just jumped into a vat of sludge themselves. Why can't you guys see the dangers ahead for West Ham? The moment they leave Upton Park, West Ham will no longer have a ground of their own. What happens if they ever hit hard times and go back to the Championship, or worse? If they ended up potless, that £2million in rent for the Olympic Stadium might not seem so cheap. And you know the rules, if you can't afford the rent, you're out. Look at every club that has hit skid row. I can't emphasise enough the importance of owning your ground. And every person I speak to who has the club's future at heart does not want to move. Ian G, Walton-on-Thames

I don’t know a fan of any club who would not be nervous at the idea of renting a stadium. I would imagine, though, that the people doing the deal have considered it very thoroughly and conclude that, whatever league West Ham are in, they should be able to afford even an index-linked £2m annual rent. I think this is a modern phenomenon, supporters thinking they know better than the people with the numbers in front of them. It is based on the mismanagement of a handful of poorly-run, rogue clubs. The current owners of West Ham are not in that category.



Maybe it's because they're Londoners: (from left) David Sullivan, Boris Johnson, Karren Brady, Mayor of Newham Sir Robin Wales and David Gold were all smiles outside the Olympic Stadium

No one can blame West Ham for taking up an amazing opportunity. The Government should be looking very hard at the buffoons who scoped a stadium for one event and no future use without major redevelopment. Hold to account the people who are responsible for building the white elephant. Eric the Red, Manchester

This is not a problem for British taxpayers alone. Politicians, hangers-on, even well-intentioned people, decide that they need to build structures for sports events and trip over each other to enthuse, explain the need and benefits of pursuing such an endeavour. Alas, with rare exceptions, the taxpayer ends-up paying for it. Alex, Angola.



Didn't the people organising our Olympics watch the programmes about the Greek venues, how they ended up as worthless ghost towns? It seems to me the people given the responsibility are very confident and good at talking, but don't have a lot of common sense. It’s well presented hot air.

Pete McNerney, Liverpool



Well said those men.



.....................................................................................................................

You're missing the point as regards West Ham and the Olympic Stadium. Yes, of course they were the obvious anchor tenants but what people are unhappy about is the deal that got done. Why should multi-millionaires get a facility like that and only chip in £15m for conversion cost and £2m a year rent? They will keep the funds from selling Upton Park, double the matchday ticket revenue and benefit from an enhanced Sky package from next year. West Ham needed the deal as much as the government did but you'd never know it from the way negotiations were handled.

Pete Channing, East Horsley

Let’s test that theory. If the sellers walked away, what would have happened to West Ham? They would continue at a much-loved, fit for purpose stadium that they can fill almost every week. If West Ham walked, the government are left with, what? The imaginary Grand Prix or the football club with 3,500 fans? Could Leyton Orient afford that £15m, or the annual £2m? Who needed the deal, do you say? Face it, Pete, if the sellers could have driven a harder bargain, they would.



99 problems but the pitch ain't one: Jay Z is set to perform on the site of last summer's Olympic Games

This is a disgrace. I am glad the Tottenham bid failed as we are much happier with our proposed stadium locally. However, considering Spurs were offering to rebuild the entire stadium and pay for it, that West Ham were chosen is mind-boggling because the numbers don't add up. I'm glad West Ham have got it, but surely they should pay for it. Martin, London

They are paying for it, Martin. They are paying what it is worth.



.....................................................................................................................

It may take a while to recoup the money but this is the best option for the country. Nothing will get the money back like a Premier League football club. Apart from the £15m, West Ham bring a lot to the table in terms of fans who will use the catering facilities and television exposure, meaning stadium sponsors will pay through the nose. It will be used regularly and still have a legacy.

Andy Phipps, London



The naming rights issue is a huge one, Andy. What would naming rights be worth if Leyton Orient were tenants with minimal television exposure, for instance? Or would it be called the Matchroom Olympic Stadium?



.....................................................................................................................

Yes, the public will own the stadium for the next 99 years. Martin makes this out to be a great justification for the bid, but in practice it just means that we get stiffed with the cost of upkeep and development, while West Ham pay a peppercorn rent and get massively increased revenue.

Nogbad T. Bad, Aberdeen

Actually, once the government makes the venue fit for purpose, West Ham are responsible for the upkeep, and can be evicted if they renege on this deal.



Not a hammer: But there were seven other events in the heptathlon as Jessica Ennis won gold

Perhaps they won't fill it, but here's an idea: make tickets available for working-class families that otherwise wouldn't be able to afford to watch Premier League football. Distribute tickets to local schools, get people into the game that otherwise wouldn't have a hope in hell of watching it. JasoninMadrid, Madrid

And all that is planned, Jason.



.....................................................................................................................

Does anyone seriously believe that Daniel Levy ever had any intention of moving Tottenham to Stratford? Wasn’t it purely a case of him wanting leverage with Haringey council? Come on people, wake up. NickP88, Chelmsford

Indeed. Maybe this will help.



Dedicated to James and all at Venus, thanks for the memories...

Can’t wait until West Ham play Wigan Athletic, Stoke City, Queens Park Rangers or Fulham and there is a half-empty stadium. Terry1958, London

Yes, because its packed to the rafters and making fortunes for us all now.

.....................................................................................................................

So at £2m a year, which will be recouped in about three home matches, they only get to use the stadium for football games, is that right (1)? So do they get the profits from food and drink sales on match day (2)? They don't own the stadium so can't get any money from concerts right (3)? They won't be able to sell the naming rights for the stadium will they, because they don't own it, right or wrong (4)? 'The entire country could have had a crack at getting it working again,' you say, but didn't Spurs want a crack at it (5)? Why can't Orient rent it on days West Ham aren't playing, like a sports centre (6). And you support who again (7)? Baba O'Riley if you're gonna play The Who (8).

The Facehead, Newquay

In turn: (1) yes, (2) no they don’t, (3) no they won’t, (4) right, (5) no Spurs pulled out and stayed in north London, (6) they could but they aren’t bringing much to the party and West Ham do need some identity at the stadium for it to be worth the while. (7) And the club I grew up supporting is well documented. As is the fact I don’t do requests. (8) I’m not Simon Bates, mate.

No requests: But you mentioned The Who so here they are on The Magic Bus... with girls and a baby elephant

People seem to be upset that West Ham aren't planning on paying more than £15m towards the stadium to get it ready, with the other £150m coming from the tax payer. This is not West Ham's problem really; it's akin to agreeing to rent a flat. Your new landlord would be expected to get it fit for purpose; not ask you to cover the bill for the mess the last tenants left. Zak Adams, The Elephant

I think this deal is good for the taxpayer and West Ham. The rent starts at £2million and is index linked so will increase. The stadium will be used for athletics as UK Athletics wanted and for concerts, the Rugby World Cup, possibly cricket and other sports including potentially the Commonwealth Games. None of this benefits West Ham financially and the profits will go to the state. West Ham are an anchor tenant in a multi-use stadium. Eastsider, London



Howling in the wind, foIks. Howling in the wind. Logic gets you nowhere in this world.



.....................................................................................................................

Take West Ham out of the equation and the tax payer would be paying far more, because athletics won't fill the stadium on a regular weekly basis nor will any other format. This is the best option all round. Will West Ham fill it? If they target the young who cannot afford the ridiculous prices of football with reduced tickets, then there is every chance they can and in doing so give football back, at least partially, to the kids and inspire future generations of football supporters that would otherwise have little chance to attend top-flight football. Terence Bates, London

It is precisely this that Barry Hearn finds so worrying. He thinks subsidised tickets will steal the next generation of Leyton Orient fans. I find it ironic that we keep banging on about how expensive football is and then when a club proposes cheaper tickets, everyone gets the vapours. Orient are a niche club with a niche following passed down through generations. Orient fans will continue to father Orient fans, no matter how many freebies are available up the road. They won’t ever be Manchester United but they’ll be fine.

What a night: The opening ceremony lit up the London sky last year

It makes me feel quite depressed. Britain had the most cultured and technologically advanced stadium in the world and it was sold. Bring back the Olympics in 2024, Britain needs its party atmosphere. Ashy, Preston

Get real, son.



.....................................................................................................................

Why are the football authorities and media so happy to steamroller Leyton Orient? Anybody would think they only care about Premiership clubs. Paul, Milton Keynes

Maybe you are not a Milton Keynes Dons fan, Paul, but if you are please forgive me the hollow laugh.



.....................................................................................................................

No mention made of the future of Leyton Orient, then. The Manxman, Isle of Man

Yes, I’m told in Manchester United’s boardroom they speak of little else.



And it’s all over. Thanks for playing. The debate takes a short break next week, so talk amongst yourselves for a while. Maybe you can persuade that bloke from Newquay to stick on The Who, if you’re missing the musical accompaniment.



I’ll leave you with this one. I used to be in a band called the Academic Hamiltons. We weren’t as good as our name. This promoter asked us to play a benefit gig for the unemployed at Poplar Civic Hall. We were undecided as the unemployed without doubt had more money than we’d ever made from being the Academic Hamiltons.



'This is a big chance for you boys,' the promoter said. 'I’ve just turned down The Who.'



Our lead guitarist was a bloke called Tony Billings. Good bloke, Tone.



'Just turned down The Who, mate?' he said. 'What, on your f***ing stereo?'

The Academic Hamiltons became The Company She Keeps (with a far superior drummer). This is well worth a listen. See you soon.

rank_198.title: Classical musicians call for UK tax breaks similar to those given to foreign sports stars
rank_198.text:
Classical musicians call for UK tax breaks similar to those given to foreign sports stars

Classical musicians who visit Britain say they should receive tax breaks similar to those offered to foreign sport stars.

Orchestra leaders says it is unfair top athletes are exempt from large tax bills on UK earnings to encourage them to compete. But they say talented musicians are subject to an ‘aggressive’ tax regime in an ‘intensely bureaucratic’ system.

Chancellor George Osborne has confirmed athletes participating in this summer’s London Grand Prix will not face punitive taxes on their earnings.

Sour notes: 35 orchestras and classical musicians groups demand the same tax breaks enjoyed by athletes in an open letter to George Osborne

Usain Bolt is one of the athletes who will benefit when he comes to race at the event in July. He has not competed in the UK since 2009 except at the Olympics due to the huge tax bill he would face on his 160,000 fee per appearance not including sponsorship fees.

Non-resident foreign footballers and team officials competing in this month’s Uefa Champions’ League Final at Wembley were given a similar tax-free status in last year’s Budget, as Uefa requires that countries which host the final ‘do not levy domestic tax on non-resident players and team officials involved in the final’.

An open letter to the Daily Telegraph signed by 35 orchestras and classical musicians group states: ‘Our major cultural events and festivals are no less relevant than the Champions League Final or the London Athletics Grand Prix.’

‘International tax conventions adopted by the British Government arbitrarily treat artists and musicians as well as sportspersons and footballers differently from other categories of taxpayer.

However this is compounded by the Government choosing to exempt foreign sports personalities from withholding tax to encourage major sports events to take place in Britain, while leaving in place an aggressive tax regime for visiting musicians and artists.’

No tax: Athletes, including champion Usain Bolt, participating in this summer¿s London Grand Prix will not face punitive taxes on their earnings

They say the ‘discriminatory and intensely bureaucratic’ tax regime should be amended, given that Culture secretary Maria Miller last week called for artistic groups to increase their ‘economic impact’ in order to receive public money.

They add: ‘In many cases Britain’s cultural organisations are forced to undertake arduous and time-consuming paperwork only to demonstrate that no tax is due at all.

‘We would support any move that enabled British orchestras and concert halls to continue to attract the world’s finest musicians and to compete in the global marketplace, to enable them to survive during these difficult times.’

George Osborne said of Usain Bolt’s appearance in London this summer: ‘The Government is determined to do everything possible to secure the Olympic legacy and I am delighted to grant this exemption.’

The musicians hit back saying: ‘If we are looking to establish a legacy from the 2012 Olympic Games, we should be doing all we can to sustain the legacy of the Cultural Olympiad as well.’

rank_10.title: MARTIN SAMUEL - THE DEBATE: Olympic legacy? The party's over
rank_10.text:
Olympic legacy? The party's over... people need to suck it up and stop waiting for David Cameron to buy them a new bike





This week a visit to Philadelphia and the famous Rocky Steps produced a column on the fleeting, uncontrollable nature of legacy.



Obviously, we have a rather large sporting legacy project under scrutiny in Britain, and it brought a wide-ranging response.



Now, to completely understand the first post, from Matty in Glasgow, you have to rewind to the original column and its assertion that legacy is a random creature and the most influential album of 1967 has proven to be not the massively popular and ground-breaking Sergeant Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band by The Beatles, but something rather more confrontational and obscure that came out of Andy Warhol’s arthouse set in New York. It gets a little noisy from here, though, mind you. Hold on to your hats.



Yeah, but Sergeant Pepper has got A Day In The Life on it, which is perfection. Matty, Glasgow

Yes it is, but the Velvet Underground and Nico has got this on it, which changes the way music sounds, Matt. Forever.

An Olympic legacy? I thought everyone recognised that for the joke it was, just an excuse to justify the £9billion. We don't do legacy. Look at the Millennium Dome. That was supposed to be a cultural landmark for the nation and what is it now? A music venue. Sgtpluck, Almeria, Spain

While I am always loathe to accept lectures on our nation from people whose address suggests they have opted out of it, I realise that Sergeant here could be on holiday or may only have emigrated last Tuesday, so I’ll not be too presumptuous. His point about the Millennium Dome, however, misses the target. The bigger scandal is that it is now one of the most successful music venues in Europe and it took an America company, AEG, to realise this project. When our government had the Dome, the thing lay dormant costing millions in maintenance. It was a foolish extravagance from the start but surely it is the paucity of imagination on the part of the government once it had served its initial purpose that is the real scandal.

............................................................................................................

If we spent £9bn on the Olympics it is a bargain compared to the £20bn cost of the Sochi Winter Olympics next year. So much needless negativity. TomDWilliams88, Norwich

So because the Russians have blown even more for no good reason that makes our expenditure right? I doubt if the great economists of the 20th century would share your rather bizarre fiscal theories, Tom. To be fair, some real dopes could probably spot the flaw in this one, too.

The start of the party: Fireworks at the Olympic Stadium lit up London at last summer's opening ceremony

If you want to see a grassroots success story that was undoubtedly boosted by the Olympics then take a look at Parkrun. What started off in Bushy Park in 2004 with just 13 runners now has 267 events operating every Saturday morning every week, and they are all free to enter and organised by volunteers. As of this Saturday 345,660 unique runners have completed 2,691,840 runs, all for free, and thousands give their time to make it happen. This is true grassroots stuff - from absolute beginners, through entire families with kids running with parents and grandparents, through club runners and even to double Olympic champions, Parkrun is for everybody of all ages, possibly like no other event. It's what sport can be about when you step away from the millionaire wages and return it to the people. Give them a chance and they will embrace it. Running Man, Datchet

Sounds impressive, Running Man. Although your moniker suggests you were an enthusiast to begin with. I’m not trying to find obstacles here, the Parkrun movement is a great success and very admirable, but clearly it did not go from 13 to 345,660 participants in the space of less than a year since the Olympics. There was already forward momentum. The key is establishing how many have been directly inspired by London 2012. I’m sure there are a number but would argue that the influence of family and friends in getting people active is often more powerful than legacy projects. Still, it’s obviously a force for good, so please don’t think I’m knocking it.

Leap of faith: Jessica Ennis-Hill was one of the gold medal winners expected to inspire a generation

Not that I frequent the gym anymore, but I have seen more people out running and Halfords must have made a killing as the roads around my way are full of cyclists of all shapes and sizes. Gamesmaker, Suffolk

Well, I do frequent the gym – I know, I know, but it’s true nonetheless and all logged on computer for those requiring documentary evidence – and it has been the same old faces for some while now. Didn’t really change much after the Olympics, either. As for cycling, depends where you live. I’m in a forest and cyclist numbers have been increasing for many years, long before the Olympics. The same in central London. The government and various London mayors spent fortunes trying to get the city out of cars and onto bikes so, again, I’m sceptical about how much of this is Olympic legacy, and how much alternate factors. How desperate do you think UK Sport were to justify Olympic expenditure? And even they couldn’t come up with the figures.

The games were never going to have a legacy with the Tories in power. Predictably, as soon as they stopped leeching off the success of our athletes they instantly cut the funding for every sport. Without this, mass participation was never going to occur. Not looking forward to us going back to the days of only winning one gold medal at the Games because the Tories won't support sport properly. Big Bruce, Surrey

My old house had a giant school playing field at the bottom of it. The land was the match of a great many independent schools in the area, and better than some, but the school itself was failing. I said all along it should have been reinvented at a specialist sports academy. Rugby pitches, football pitches, all-weather hockey, a proper running track, build a swimming pool – which the town didn’t have so there could be dual community use – a state of the art gym and indoor sports arena. They could have made it the school that every sporty kid in Essex wanted to attend, rather than the one that had the problem surplus from the surrounding areas dumped on it due to a downward spiral.



What happened? Sold much of the land to private housing to fund the new school buildings which are now adjacent to bog standard, limited space playing fields. And guess who was in power throughout this, Bruce? Labour. So don’t give me this party political crap. Nobody is sitting on a couch watching reruns of Total Wipeout because David Cameron doesn’t want to subsidise basketball. If you’ve got a street outside you can go for a run. I don’t know if you’ve noticed, mate, but we’re skint. We can barely afford hospitals let alone volleyball. Something has got to give.



'We're skint. We can barely afford hospitals, let alone volleyball,' was part of Martin's reply to Big Bruce

About a month after the Olympics, our sports centre where we'd been playing basketball for over 10 years, decided to stop our Sunday night session because it wasn't bringing in enough money. Not only was this a blow for the dedicated player, it was a good way for people new to London to find a group of people with a similar interest. We had guys from all over Europe, America, Australia and New Zealand and the standard was quite high (some people had played in their respective national leagues or colleges). I joined after someone pulled a knife at a previous gym I used, so we worked hard to make it a place where new players felt welcome and safe, and younger ones could come and learn how to play properly. Now we have to organize it as a private session, at three times the cost, and it isn't really open to new people. AAA, London

You have my sympathy, Triple A. Without knowing the circumstances of how much the session was costing the council, however, and whether indeed the sports centre was council owned, or contracted out, it is hard to call. It does seem a lack of imagination on the part of your sports centre landlords to fail to see the positives of your previous session. Again though, in times of recession, it is hard to be too judgemental because everyone is under budgetary pressure. One imagines your council is still finding money for other stuff though; stuff that, as ever, seems more for them than you.

............................................................................................................

My son watched the Games for the first time and has been going to our local athletics club every Tuesday. He has had his eyes opened to a whole world of sports. It needs funding, though, as most of these clubs rely on volunteers. Ant, Manchester

That’s great, Ant. I’m glad the Olympics inspired him. But a question: what do you suggest we lose to fund community athletics? We spent £9bn being inspirational. At what point has sport got to look after itself?



Some things will last: We all know Mo Farah's celebration following his two gold medals at London 2012

A legacy means not selling off playing fields and making sports cheap to play. Mark, Watford

Yes, but the £9bn that would have done that went on a three-week party for the elite.

............................................................................................................

But it really did make British people proud to be British. The show was amazing.

Ed Dzeko, Coventry.

Yes, but now the party’s over, so everybody needs to suck it up and stop waiting for David Cameron to buy them a new bike. And by the way, Ed, anyone who needed an Olympics to make them proud of a country that gave the world Shakespeare, JM Turner, Brunel, the industrial revolution, William Blake, the internet, Underworld and the NHS should be forced to live in Finland.

On your bike: People need to stop waiting for David Cameron... the party is over



'London spent £9billion on an Olympics designed to inspire a generation'. Did it really Martin? No input from the rest of the country? Really? Any reference to the true cost of the London Olympics being £24bn, the vast majority of this spent on upgrading public transport infrastructure? What about the bonuses paid for underground drivers to work during this period? The athletic legacy might not have been all that was expected, but London, and Londoners, did very well out of the Olympics. The rest of the country just got the bill. Knowsbetterthanyou, Leicester

In that sentence from the column, ‘London’ is plainly shorthand for the London Olympic movement, not a direct reference to the city. I thought that much was obvious. Why not ask my dad how much the Olympics and Olympic regeneration has benefited Londoners? It has almost cost him his business due to the local upheaval. I’ll write about it in painstaking detail one day: the truth about legacy. It is certainly not the golden gift for all Londoners that is imagined in the provinces, unless you thought what the capital needed was another shopping centre. Anyway, where were we meant to hold the Games? Leicester? They can’t even get a statue up to Joe Orton. Manchester had been trying to get the Olympics for years and the IOC basically told our organisers that unless London bid we had no chance. If we wanted an Olympics, it was London or nothing, I’m afraid. The debate is around the worth of the pursuit, not the location.

Boxing clever: A trip to Philadelphia - where Rocky climbed the famous steps - inspired this week's column

The £9bn was spent in the UK, created work for companies and 60,000 jobs for people who then paid tax and spent their wages in the country. Where did you think the money went? The economy had the benefit in the seven years leading up to the Games. What planet are you on?

GerryR, London

And yet, somehow, we’re still up to our necks in it. Despite the fortunes generated, somehow the economy is still a bust, our credit rating has been downgraded and we are scrapping desperately to avoid triple dip recession. So maybe there is more to governance than just building a few stadiums and watching the money roll in. As for the jobs, look how many went to previously unemployed workers in the five London boroughs that hosted the Olympics. Not 60,000 mate. Not even sure they got to four figures when the building was being done.

Iconic: Stallone and the Rocky films have done wonders for the city of Philadelphia

Whenever another billion or two was needed to justify the spiralling London 2012 costs, any number of LOCOG members went before the TV cameras and duly punctuated every sentence with the word legacy. They tossed it around like confetti at a wedding, its overuse reminiscent of the manner in which Tony Blair's cabinet, almost out of nowhere, began using the term weapons of mass destruction to soften up the British public for a likely Iraq invasion. Lord Coe grossly exaggerated his fuzzy and blurred vision for a participative legacy. The same is also true of Blair and his phantom WMDs. A participative legacy will always be hit and miss unless some kind of nudging or underpinning policy is established to help it move from desirable aspiration to grass roots reality. There never was a plan. Ken Livingstone couldn't care less about sport, only about East London's regeneration. To this end, his legacy has been the most real and visually tangible.

Kismet1001, London

rank_13.title: JOANNA ROWSELL: It's great to keep the Olympic legacy going at events such as the London Youth Games
rank_13.text:
JOANNA ROWSELL: It's great to keep the Olympic legacy going at events such as the London Youth Games



This morning I went to the opening ceremony of the Balfour Beatty London Youth Games finals at Crystal Palace National Sports Centre.



This is Europe’s largest annual youth sports event, featuring 80 competitions across 30 sports where competitors compete for their London Borough. This weekend is the finals weekend where the overall winning London Borough will be announced.



One of my first ever cycling races was this event back in 2004 where I competed for Sutton. I was a still a beginner but felt honoured to represent my borough and the competition between the different boroughs was fierce! I think events like this are really important as part of the legacy of the London Olympics and it was great to see so many kids out enjoying lots of different sports all in one place.

Champagne moment: Joanna Rowsell (centre) celebrates after winning the women's time trial at the National Road Race Championships in Glasgow last month

My first role was to carry the flame and light the cauldron to open the Games and I was joined by Warren Russell from the dance group Diversity, who was also a former competitor in the LYG in gymnastics.



After the formalities there was time to watch some sport before a Q and A session with some primary school children. These are always entertaining as the kids ask some very unusual questions. We were asked what our favourite food was, to which Warren said the very healthy sweet potato along with steak. I on the other hand said mine was chocolate! (Confessions of an athlete!)



Tough questions: Rowsell was grilled by primary school children

The best question though was from one girl wanting to know what pyjamas we wear... I’ve never had that one before! She was chuffed to hear I have a onesie and proudly told me she has one too.

I have had a break from training following the National Championships in Glasgow two weeks ago as I had my tonsils out last week. I am a frequent tonsillitis sufferer so I had the operation to take them out as a precautionary measure ahead of the next track season. I am on the mend now and riding steady before getting back into hard training next week. I have a super busy competition schedule coming up now for the rest of the road season and will carry on straight into the track season when the two seasons overlap in September so a bit of down time now should do me good.

rank_49.title: 50 playing fields sold in three years: Sell-off is a 'threat to our Olympic legacy'
rank_49.text:
Fifty playing fields sold in three years: Sell-off is a 'threat to our Olympic legacy'

Michael Gove under fire for jeopardising legacy from London 2012

17 sports pitches disappear each year, most in Tory council areas



Labour says 'parents will be shocked' by end of rules protecting fields



Michael Gove was accused of jeopardising Britain’s Olympic legacy yesterday as it emerged he allowed schools to sell off 50 playing fields over the past three years.

On average, 17 are closed every year, most in Conservative local authorities.

The figures make a mockery of a pledge to protect them in the Coalition agreement.

Olympic dreams: There is growing anger that 50 school playing fields have been sold over the past three years, which could jeopardise the future of British sport, said Shadow education secretary Stephen Twigg

This followed the huge outcry over Labour disposing of playing fields at the slightly higher rate of 28 each year.

Shadow education secretary Stephen Twigg accused the Government of damaging sport. He said: ‘David Cameron and Michael Gove are putting the Olympic legacy at risk.

‘Parents will be shocked that the Tory-led Government is still selling off playing fields.’

Details of plans to scrap rules on schools keeping a set amount of playing field space for team sports emerged on the eve of last year’s Olympics.

New rules that came into force months later stated only that ‘suitable’ outdoor space should be provided for sport and play.

Education secretary Michael Gove is under fire after it emerged that 17 school fields are closed every year, most in Conservative local authorities.

At the time, 35 applications to dispose of playing fields had been made – 30 by Tory councils, four by Labour-run authorities and one by a Lib Dem council.

The Education Secretary initially said 21 had been approved – only to have to apologise and say the figure was actually 30.

The deals included the sale of a football pitch to a developer by Barton Peveril Sixth Form College in Hampshire, whose former pupils include gold medal-winning cyclist Dani King.



Elliott School in Putney, south London, was allowed to sell five acres of fields with six tennis courts, a football pitch and a playground to make way for luxury housing.

Several sales have gone ahead against the advice of the independent playing fields panel.



Only five have been rejected by the Department for Education. The DfE claims the rule change is needed to allow more school places to be created quickly.

But Labour has warned that cuts in schools’ capital budgets are leading to ‘salami slicing’ of school pitches.

A total of 242 playing fields were sold off under Tony Blair or Gordon Brown from November 2001 to May 2010.



The DfE said last night that about two-thirds of disposals followed the closure or merger of schools.

A spokesman added: ‘The number of playing fields approved for disposal by the Government is falling.’



Several sales have gone ahead against the advice of the independent playing fields panel.

She said it was schools and their local authorities that proposed to convert this ‘often surplus or unused land to invest in sport or education’.

The charity Fields in Trust said the DfE was now more ‘transparent’ about the decisions.



But chief executive Helen Griffiths warned: ‘The focus now must be on ensuring that the growing body of [independently run] academies and free schools are subject to the same processes as local education authority maintained schools.

rank_8.title: Our Olympic legacy... a new shopping centre for Croydon: South London town to benefit as Games 'boost UK economy by £10million'
rank_8.text:
Our Olympic legacy... a new shopping centre for Croydon: South London town to benefit as Games 'boost UK economy by £10million'

Report boasts of £9.9bn trade boost from Olympic and Paralympic Games

Every trade deal done since August has been linked to London 2012

Business Secretary Vince Cable admits claiming credit for some jobs and investment which would have happened regardless



Small businesses say they did not see boom for areas outside London



The Olympics have already given a £10billion boost to the British economy, ministers claimed yesterday.

In a glossy 70-page brochure, ministers put the trade boom from the Games slightly higher than the cost of staging them last summer.

But the figures were immediately met with scepticism as the report directly linked the Olympics effect to building projects that included a shopping centre in Croydon, South London.

Boom: As the anniversary of the Opening Ceremony approaches, the government claims the London 2012 Games brought a £9.9billion boost to the UK economy

Anniversary: One year on from London 2012 a 30,000-strong crowd enjoyed a day in the sun at the Go Local concert at London's Olympic Park

Business Secretary Vince Cable conceded the figure was ‘not a rigorous academic approach’ and some of the investment ‘would have happened anyway’.

But he said London 2012 had been a catalyst for foreign investment into the UK and made projects progress more quickly than they otherwise would have.

In a report from the Government and the Mayor of London, it was claimed that the Games had already generated £9.9billion for the economy, exceeding their £9.3billion cost.

This includes £2.5billion in projects such as the development of South London’s Battersea Power Station backed by Malaysia, a Chinese-funded regeneration of London’s Royal Albert Docks, and the forthcoming Westfield shopping centre in Croydon.

Prime Minister David travelled to the Olympic Park to hand out goody bags to Olympic Games Makers who were there to celebrate one year on from the Olympic and Paralympic Games

Mr Cameron joined London Mayor Boris Johnson to see construction work which is transforming the site into the Queen Elizabeth Olympic park which will be open later this month

The Australian firm – which already has two Westfield centres in London, including one next to the Olympic Stadium in Stratford – signed a £1billion deal in January to revamp an existing shopping centre in Croydon, after being in talks since 2011.



The rest is made up of £5.9billion of additional sales and overseas sports contracts awarded to British firms for events such as the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Olympics, both in Brazil.

By 2020, the Games could add £41billion of value to the economy, the report says.



Mr Cable, speaking on BBC Radio 4’s Today programme, said: ‘Would this have happened anyway?



Some of these activities clearly would, but the Olympics were a key catalyst in making those investment decisions real.’

Contracts: The report suggests that since the Olympic Park closed last summer British companies have gone on to win contracts for the Olympic and Paralympic Games in Rio

Rebuilding: Construction workers have been on site since the closing ceremony preparing the venues to be reopened to the public

But Labour’s Lord Harris, chairman of Parliament’s Olympic and Paralympic Legacy Committee, said: ‘I’m afraid you have to take all of these figures with a large pinch of salt.’



Mr Cable said: ‘The answer we’ve had with a lot of the high-profile investment is that a lot of the key negotiations [with investors] came out of the events that we organised around the Olympics.



An enormous amount of effort was put in to try to attract big inward investment, to try to support British businesses to get business on the back of it.’



During the Games, lavish hospitality was extended to foreign dignitaries and business leaders at the British Business Embassy in Lancaster House in London, in the hope of attracting a trade windfall.



David Cameron yesterday said: ‘This £9.9billion boost to the UK economy is a reminder to the world that, if you want the best, if you want professionalism, if you want jobs done on time and on budget, then you should think British.’

Claiming credit: Business Secretary Vince Cable admitted some of the investment would have happened anyway while London Mayor Boris Johnson claimed a new shopping centre in Croydon could be attributed to the Olympics

Doing deals: David Cameron used the Games to meet business and political leaders in London, including Russian President Vladimir Putin at a judo event

rank_166.title: Sebastian Coe: Drug cheats are driving bulldozer through our history
rank_166.text:
On first anniversary of greatest Olympics, Coe warns: Drug cheats are driving bulldozer through our history

A full year has passed since a flame flared, a flag flew and a glorious spectacle unfolded. But as the nation celebrates an anniversary week of rose-tinted reverie, the man who gave us the London Olympics is in no mood for nostalgia. With the future of his tainted sport at stake, Sebastian Coe is preparing to fight a bloody battle.

The revelation that the sprinters Tyson Gay and Asafa Powell had failed tests for banned drugs left Lord Coe 'absolutely livid; angrier than I've been for a long time'. As a vice-president of the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF), he has the power to translate that anger into effective action. And the consequences of failure could not be more hazardous.

Clean win: No doubts about London 2012 100m gold medalist Usain Bolt ¿ but (left to right) Justin Gatlin, Yohan Blake, Tyson Gay and Asafa Powell now all have drug-test history

The World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) currently impose a two-year ban on first offenders. This represents a compromise by athletics, which had pushed for mandatory four-year bans.

Coe bitterly regrets the concession. 'We shouldn't have sold the pass, but we did,' he admits. 'We did it because it made life easier for some sports. It took them from nothing to two years. But it did our sport no favours at all. I'm no longer prepared to sit here and say that it's acceptable, because it isn't. We've got to get rid of the cheats, because if we get rid of them, we'll be giving clean athletes the chance to compete fairly and win things. That's what it's about.

'I recognise that we live in a legal world where a life ban is not going to happen. We would lose that in any court. But four years should be the penalty. The proportional damage of a high profile case in my sport is significantly greater than in most other sports. We are different. If some sports are happy with two years, that's fine. But we're too high-profile now to withstand this kind of abuse indefinitely. Four years sends a message, it really does affect a career. I'm going to fight for this, fight all the way.'

Those of us who have observed Coe down the decades will recognise a classic twin-pronged technique at work here. As an idealist, he really does feel fervently about this moral issue. Indeed, if he does not win his case, then all the signs suggest that he would walk away from his position at the IAAF.

But, as a politician, he is aware that most WADA board members are well-disposed to four-year bans, which the organisation's new code is expected to introduce from 2015 when it is approved at the World Conference on Doping in Sport in Johannesburg in November. Coe is, therefore, seeking to accelerate the process and bring along the doubters.



Upset: Lord Coe was 'absolutely livid' at latest doping scandal

Fierce passion and shrewd pragmatism; London's success in staging the most stunning Games in Olympic history owes a huge debt to that combination. His current anger aside, Coe is relishing the chance to revisit recent history, culminating in the Anniversary Games in the Olympic Park over three days next weekend. 'It's nice when people come up to me on the street and talk about what it meant to them,' he says.

'It had a really big impact, and I don't think we realised it at the time. For those of us working on the Games, it just went too quickly. I remember my Dad saying to me: "You'll get to the age of 40, and you'll remember everything. Then, suddenly, you'll be 70, and you won't have noticed the passing years." I'm sure he was right.

'I was in Singapore in 2005, trying to win the right to stage the Games. Next thing I knew, I was standing in a holding room in the Olympic Stadium, scribbling notes on a piece of paper before speaking to an audience of four billion people. Madness. Of course, I was thrilled that it all went so well, and so safely.

'I mean, we were in Singapore when we heard about the London bombs. From the very first day, we had that act of barbarity in our minds. So we all sat through London saying: "Let's just get through another day, then another, and another." We all knew what the real risk was: a group of people standing by the roadside watching, say, Bradley Wiggins coming past on the big screen. And just at that moment, something unspeakable happening. Mercifully, it never did.'

Yet the dizzy success of Olympic and Paralympic Games was, in Coe's view 'only the midway point of the story'. As he says: 'This was a 20-year journey: two years to win the right to bid. Hats in the ring in 2003. Two years of criss-crossing the globe to win the vote. Another seven years to deliver it.'



Stunning: London 2012 was a dazzling success

And then, after bringing off the Games, there began the work of delivering the legacy. Coe is aware that the Olympic legacy is, for some, an inviting target. So he says, cautiously: 'I actually think the first year after the Games has had a very promising start. I'm not going to over-claim, but we do have more people playing sport - a million and a half more than in 2005.

'We've now got Join In, connecting clubs and groups with the community. More than 10,000 events have already registered for the Join In Summer. We have put £150million into primary schools for sport. British businesses have reported an extraordinary dividend from markets that have opened up to them because of the Games. Visitor numbers and visitor spend are up significantly. Eight venues in the Olympic Park now have a secure home.

'We also have a decade of sport ahead which is the envy of the world, in large part because our governing bodies gained confidence from the Games. There isn't a world championship worth its name that isn't going to be put on in this country over the next 10 years. We can't allow these events to just be jewels in the landscape and not convert kids to sport. We haven't done that well in the past. We didn't make as much of winning the 2003 Rugby World Cup as we should have done. We won a hockey gold medal at the Olympics of 1988, and we didn't make the most of that.

'Lots of problems, lots of difficulties. And yet, I would have settled for it in the first year of the second half of the journey.'

The claim is measured and the tone reasonable, but suddenly he remembers the crushing blow that track and field has suffered through the drug cheats. 'You know, the thing that makes me most angry is the fact that they're trashing our history,' he says. 'It's like driving a bulldozer through a war cemetery.

'It is appalling that they don't understand what people like Jesse Owens, Herb Elliot and Fanny Blankers-Koen meant in our sport. If you don't understand your history, if you don't understand where you come from, then it might even look acceptable to cheat with drugs. Well, it's bloody not.'

Seb Coe's message was safely delivered. Now he could enjoy his anniversary.

rank_68.title: Olympics bosses receive £2.8million in golden goodbyes despite knowing their jobs would be axed after 2012
rank_68.text:
Olympics bosses receive £2.8million in golden goodbyes despite knowing their jobs would be axed after 2012

All 144 staff who left Olympic Delivery Authority received pay-offs last year



Four bosses had £261,000 in exit payments within months of London 2012



ODA chief executive Dennis Hone now head of Olympic legacy body

Critics condemned 'utter disregard' for use of public money



London Olympics bosses received £2.8million in pay-offs despite knowing their jobs would end after the 2012 Games.

All 144 people who left the Olympic Delivery Authority last year received redundancy pay as the agency was wound down.

Four executives received £261,000 in exit payments after leaving within months of the closing ceremony last summer.

Pay-offs: Every person who left the Olympic Delivery Authority last year received redundancy pay, despite knowing their jobs would not last beyond the 2012 Games

The pay-offs will raise questions about the use of public money because all of the recipients will have known their jobs were not going to last far beyond the London 2012 Games.

The ODA insisted the payments were necessary because senior managers gave up lucrative jobs elsewhere ‘with no certainty of the project's success or getting a job after the Games’.

According to the annual accounts of the ODA, a total of 144 people received redundancy pay-outs in the last year.

Three people left with pay-offs worth £70,000-£80,000, two received between £50,000-£60,000 and two between £40,000 and £50,000. Almost half received between £10,000 and £20,000.

Golden goodbye: Dennis Hone left as chief executive of the ODA with an £80,000 golden goodbye - and became head of the London Legacy Development Corporation

Matthew Sinclair, chief executive of the TaxPayers' Alliance, said: 'It beggars belief that the Olympics quango employed staff on permanent contracts .



'Taxpayers' money has been wasted on payouts that were entirely avoidable had staff contracts reflected the fact that working on the Olympics was quite obviously a temporary role.



'The utter disregard shown for value for taxpayers' money by Olympics chiefs is both shocking and worrying, especially as the government are holding up the Olympics as an example of how to manage big infrastructure projects.'

Dennis Hone, the ODA chief executive, received £929,000 in pay, bonuses and pensions during just two years in the job.

He left with a pension pot worth £1.9million. He was made redundant at the end of March, with a golden goodbye worth £80,000, as well as an immediate pension of £373,000.

But he walked into a new job as chief executive of the London Legacy Development Corporation.

According to the accounts Mr Hone was entitled to receive statutory redundancy pay and a pay-off bonus equivalent worth 60 per cent of his £233,000 salary.

It was agreed he would receive a lower ‘terminal bonus’ of 49 per cent of his salary and half of it will only be paid once the sale is completed on the East Village, the athlete’s village which is being turned into homes, schools and shops.

The ODA's director of transport, Hugh Sumner, also received £73,000 in exit payments, on top of his £189,000 salary, £35,000 bonus and £23,000 employer’s pension contribution.

Simon Wright, director of venues and infrastructure, received a golden goodbye worth £72,000 when he left the ODA in November.

During seven months he earned £151,000 salary, a £35,000 bonus and £18,000 towards his pension.

Rebuilding: David Cameron joined London Mayor Boris Johnson last week to see construction work which is transforming the London 2012 site into the Queen Elizabeth Olympic park which will be open later this month

Anniversary: One year on from London 2012 a 30,000-strong crowd enjoyed a day in the sun at the Go Local concert at London's Olympic Park

Director of human resources Wendy Cartwright, who earned £177,000 last year in pay, bonuses and pension, received £36,000 in exit payment.

The ODA insisted that only Mr Hone received extra cash, with all other staff given statutory redundancy pay, any leave they were unable to take before their employment ended, and, where appropriate, payment in lieu of notice.

A spokesman added: ‘London 2012 was a unique and challenging project and a great British success story and we needed to recruit and pay for the best talent from the private and public sectors, requiring people in many cases to give up secure long-term jobs elsewhere, with no certainty of the project's success or getting a job after the Games.

‘We had to adopt a flexible approach to managing staff contracts to ensure that key people, especially directors, remained with the project throughout periods critical to its success, until such time as the ODA could be certain that their skills and knowledge were no longer required. Our staff delivered this huge project on time and under budget - in fact making savings of over £1 billion for the public purse.

‘Like other staff, Dennis Hone received performance-related pay, but this was far from guaranteed and was measured against tough performance criteria, evaluated personally and in relation to the organisation he successfully led in the critical 18 months up to the Games, during London 2012 and immediately after.

rank_199.title: As we win the Ashes Test and Tour de France, MPs say children should avoid competitive sports because it can put them off exercise for life
rank_199.text:
As we win the Ashes Test and Tour de France, MPs say children should avoid competitive sports because it can put them off exercise for life

MPs say safeguarding Britain's Olympic legacy involves getting as many children as possible to enjoy non-competitive activities

They warn competitive sports have limited appeal and a focus on winning can be counter-productive



Competitive sports put some children off exercise for life and primary schools should be told to offer less taxing alternatives, MPs have warned.

Safeguarding Britain’s Olympic legacy is about allowing as many children as possible to enjoy the health benefits of sport through non-competitive activities, they say in a report out today.

The Commons Education Committee warned that competitive team sports have a ‘limited appeal’ to some children and politicians’ focus on them can be ‘counter-productive’.

'Limited appeal': While children may look up to sporting heroes such as Tour de France winner Chris Froome (pictured) MPs warn that a focus on winning is sure to put some children off exercise

Number one: As England celebrate the euphoria of trouncing Australia in the Ashes, MPs publish a report saying shifting the focus from competitive to non-competitive sports will help tackle obesity

During the Games last summer David Cameron announced that competitive team sports would be made compulsory for all primary school children in England.

He pledged funding for new sports teachers to inspire the next generation of top athletes, and expressed concerns that Indian dance was being counted as physical education.

But the committee of MPs urged the Department for Education to make clear to schools that there should also be non-competitive activities to increase the wellbeing of all children, and help control obesity.

The committee chairman, Tory MP Graham Stuart, said the 2012 Games was a ‘magical time’ which generated ‘massive enthusiasm’ for sport among young people.

Olympic legacy: David Cameron (pictured with Olympic sailor Ben Ainslie and Paralympic swimmer Ellie Simmonds) had promised that competitive sports would become compulsory in primary schools

‘High-quality school sport is vitally important,’ he said. ‘It provides young people with opportunities to improve their education, health and well-being.



'We need to be encouraging all young people to take part in sport; whether they enjoy the competition of football, rugby or netball or prefer non-competitive activities. Schools must provide a range of activities that appeal to all.’

Competitive sports ‘can bring many benefits to young people in terms of resilience, organisation and team work’, the report said, but a focus on winning ‘can be a disincentive as a much as incentive’ for some children.

While the Government has injected £300million into primary school sports provision for the next two years, the MPs warned there is no long-term plan when that ends in 2015.

They said ministers needed to act to make sure the momentum was not lost ‘amid short-term plans and funding’ or their promises risked becoming a ‘gimmick’.

Inclusive: MPs say that safeguarding Britain's Olympic legacy means getting as many children as possible to engage with exercise rather than focusing on coming first

The committee took evidence from education think tanks, as well as the Youth Sport Trust and the Rugby Football Union, which recommended more provision for non-competitive sport – although 59 per cent of primary schools said they offer this in the form of activities such as dance.

Meanwhile 67 per cent of primaries said their pupils entered inter-school competitions.

All 17,000 primary schools in England and Wales have been given funding to improve their sports provision until 2015, and around 120 dedicated sports teachers are being trained.

Mr Stuart said: ‘We are concerned that the Government’s primary sport premium – while correctly focused – is only being given to schools for two years.

rank_12.title: They made us so proud. But I'm afraid the Olympic legacy is bitter disappointment
rank_12.text:
They made us so proud. But I'm afraid the Olympic legacy is bitter disappointment

Few of us will have any trouble remembering what we were doing exactly a year ago tonight. Along with most of the human race, we were watching one of the great spectacles of modern time.

The Queen’s debut as a Bond girl? Danny Boyle’s industrial revolution? Mr Bean? We all have a favourite moment from the opening ceremony of the London Olympics.

And even those who never got a ticket will remember the national transformation that followed. Britain suddenly felt a great deal better about itself. Until then, we hadn’t challenged the myth of our post-war, post-imperial decline.

London 2012 Olympic Games opening ceremony was ended with spectacular fireworks

There will be more of the same magic over this weekend as Jessica Ennis and the gang return to a sold-out Olympic Stadium for the Anniversary Games

Now, we were pleasantly reminded that, in fact, we were actually really rather good at colossal events; at building things and running trains on time. As it turned out, we’d also learned to win once again. With the glorious Diamond Jubilee on top, that whole summer now seems swathed in red, white and blue.

One year on, and the 2012 magic is still working. Andy Murray, the British Lions, the Ashes, the Tour de France — not to mention Prince George.

The scenes outside Buckingham Palace on Monday night were pure 2012. The crowds were cheering in every language on Earth, and even the drunks were pleasant.



One year on, and the 2012 magic is still working with athletes like Andy Murray continuing to fly the flag for Britain

And there will be more of the same over this weekend as Jessica Ennis and the gang return to a sold-out Olympic Stadium for the Anniversary Games.

To cap it all, the Government has published a shiny report claiming the Games have not only generated £9.9 billion, but that legions of idlers have been inspired to crawl off the sofa and shape up. A new slimmer, richer Britain is here. Is there no end to the miraculous powers of the rings? Or is this a moment to pause, sober up and return to reality for a moment?

For let’s recall that we were told some whopping great fibs in the run-up to the Games. Boris Johnson has repeated his ‘on time and on budget’ mantra so often, it seems to have ossified in the public mindset.

The Games were on time, of course. But on budget? The budget, when we won the bid in 2005, was £2.4 billion. Over the next seven years, it almost quadrupled to £9.3 billion. If you hired a builder for an agreed sum, and his bill went up four-fold, I don’t think you’d let him proclaim he’d been ‘on time and on budget’. You’d take him to court.

The scenes outside Buckingham Palace on Monday night were pure 2012. The crowds were cheering in every language on Earth, and even the drunks were pleasant

But then, as the Olympics would show time and again, where public money is involved, different rules apply. Hence the £2.8 million redundancy bonuses and pay-offs for various Olympic high-ups announced this week. We all knew that ‘London 2012’ was going to end in 2012. So why were these people not employed on fixed contracts?

But while there’s been no shortage of public cash to throw at grand buildings and Olympic executives, some of our sporting stars have fared less well. Despite winning the first British gold of the Games (along with fellow rower Heather Stanning), Helen Glover still has no main sponsor and can barely afford to repair her car.

Likewise, with no main sponsor, the men’s rowing team (some of whom are 6ft 8in) will have to squash into the cheapest seats at the back of the plane for next month’s world championships in Korea. Even long-jumper Greg Rutherford, one of the gold-medal heroes of ‘Super Saturday’, was dumped by Nike soon afterwards — and now lacks a sponsor.



The budget, when we won the bid in 2005, was £2.4¿billion. Over the next seven years, it almost quadrupled to £9.3¿billion

None of them ever went in to this for the money. But it’s hardly a great come-on for young athletes to know that Olympic glory is substantially less rewarding than being a lower-league footballer.

So, what of those future athletes? According to the new ‘Inspired by 2012’ legacy document, 1.4 million more people are now playing sport. But take a closer look: this figure straddles a seven-year period. The actual number of extra people playing sport in England since the 2012 Olympics is, well, none. Because the numbers have dropped by 100,000.

Look at the Sport England data on, say, the number of people who are members of sports clubs. There has been a drop of more than 200,000 since last year. Over a five-year span, there’s been a drop of 670,000.

Sport England insists that more people are playing ‘informal’ sport. ‘A lot of people now prefer to have a game of five-a-side football than join a club,’ says a spokesman. As for the decline in post-Games activity, Sport England puts that down to bad weather in March. It hardly stacks up to a sporting revolution.

Boris Johnson has repeated his 'on time and on budget' mantra so often, it seems to have ossified in the public mindset

Just this week, Sir Keith Mills, former deputy chairman of 2012, complained that a ‘barmy’ lack of co-ordination between Government departments was squandering any legacy at local level.

The greatest fib, though, was not a sporting one at all. It was Danny Boyle’s brilliantly choreographed opening-ceremony tribute to the National Health Service, ‘the envy of the world’ and all that — complete with Florence Nightingale-style nurses in starched uniforms. Had we known then what we know now — about the thousands of unnecessary deaths in recent years; the institutional, serial maltreatment of the helpless; the cover-ups and gagging orders — then there would have been more hollow laughter than applause.

Looking back, Boyle might wish he’d lionised one or two other British inventions instead. It’s not as if he was short of material: the jet engine, the railway, television — even football . . .

Just this week, Sir Keith Mills, former deputy chairman of 2012, complained that a 'barmy' lack of co-ordination between Government departments was squandering any legacy at local level

Now, I freely admit that I was what Boris Johnson called an Olympic ‘doom-monger’. I genuinely feared we were going to end up with a similar multi-billion-pound shambles to the one you still find in Athens, host of the 2004 Games. A year afterwards, I was apprehended there by the police for watching a property developer bulldozing a supposed ‘legacy’ venue. On my last trip, I found that the grass in the Olympic softball stadium came up to my shoulders. You could keep a tiger in there, and no one would know.

There were never any doubts that our Olympic fortnight would go according to plan. But at what cost? And what would be the true legacy?

The 1976 Montreal Games almost bankrupted that city, and today its Olympic stadium has no main tenant. Likewise the Olympic stadium in Barcelona. Even Sydney, host of the great Olympiad of 2000, was left with a vast complex of redundant venues that took years and billions of dollars to sort out.

And, like many, I also resented the way that the whole of Britain had to subjugate itself to the puffed-up International Olympic Committee. When shops were threatened with prosecution for putting Olympic displays in the window, our Government should have told the IOC where they could stick their precious rings. But come that momentous evening, exactly one year ago, all those concerns simply faded away. Lord Coe and his magnificent team had taken a huge gamble, had endured seven years of carping from us doom-mongers, and delivered a triumph. As the Queen appeared to float in from on high, the brilliant originality and titanic scale of London 2012 was already sinking in.

Now that a year has passed, however, we should regain a sense of perspective. Parts of the new official report are simply Toytown accounting.

It claims, for example, that the planned redevelopment of London’s Battersea Power Station by a Malaysian consortium is a direct result of the Olympics. In fact, this grey elephant has been changing hands for the past 30 years, and a deal was in place long before the first backside sat on the first Olympic seat.

My favourite section states: ‘Bespoke economic modelling utilising an input-output framework suggests that the impacts that can already be clearly identified at this early stage will in total generate some £28 billion to £41 billion in GVA [Gross Value Added].’ Oh dear. The fibbing really has got out of hand. At least the Business Secretary, Vince Cable, had the decency to admit: ‘Would this have happened anyway? Some of these activities clearly would, but the Olympics were a key catalyst.’

Lord Harris of Haringey, the Labour chairman of the Lords’ Olympic and Paralympic Legacy Committee, is more succinct: ‘I’m afraid you have to take all of these figures with a large pinch of salt.’
