There was a worrying spike in whereabouts offences by British athletes in the year before the London Olympic Games, too. Meaning a missed test is a big deal, and just one can incur a ban, if the anti-doping legislators believe an athlete has been deliberately evasive.

So Mo Farah isn’t subject to some irrational witch-hunt. He isn’t being pursued or bullied. This is not tall poppy syndrome, build ‘em up to knock ‘em down. He works with a coach, Alberto Salazar, who has a queue of athletes and coaches making accusations against him. This led to the revelation that Farah missed a date with the testers twice prior to the 2012 Olympic Games. That isn’t a meaningless development, either.

Anxious emails were sent warning of the dire consequences of a third no-show; Farah’s agent Ricky Simms went to significant lengths to dispute the second miss on the grounds his client hadn’t heard his doorbell. All of this indicates a developing crisis treated with huge significance at the time. And if it was big for Farah then, it most certainly is for British athletics and the Olympic movement now.

Alberto Salazar has been accused of doping by a raft of former athletes and coaches

Farah celebrates after adding the European 5,000m title to his trophy cabinet last year

Farah and his Team GB colleagues are all that remain in terms of 2012 Olympic legacy. The bold predictions of a revitalised healthy nation have crumbled.

Fond memories alone are left and any suspicion around Farah threatens that happy state. Missed tests, by definition, cast doubt.

The latest figures from Sport England make depressing reading. In the last six months, 250,000 people have dropped out of sports participation. The anticipated spike in activity that would be London’s legacy never materialised.

Swimming is down 144,200, and closer to 160,000 no longer visit a gym. Hell, Britain can’t even keep its citizens interested in Zumba classes, considering dance-related fitness has also taken a hit. The cycling boom has peaked — down by over 40,000 — and the biggest racket sport, badminton, is not far behind.

Stadium legacy is equally elusive. A football club has claimed the Olympic arena, other structures have been dismantled and reduced, and the diversion of capital to the capital has actually helped forced the closure of some facilities in the regions.

So it’s the sport. That is what is left. It was a marvellous party, and we loved every minute of it. Farah was at the heart of that, from his gold medal on Super Saturday to his heart-stopping triumph in the 5,000 metres a week later, arguably the run of his life.

He was Britain’s athlete of the games, a long-distance runner capable of outlasting the East Africans, a competitor of incredible resolve and courage, with a back story that encapsulated all that was positive about modern Britain.

A school age refugee from Somalia, who arrived speaking little English and at first struggled to assimilate, his rise to become the greatest long distance runner of his time was a tale of true inspiration. It was this country’s equivalent of the American dream — anybody can be anybody, with enough drive and determination. It is no exaggeration to describe Farah as a national hero.

Prime Minister David Cameron poses with Farah outside No 10 Downing Street after his 5,000m Olympic win

Spectators perform the Mobot at the Anniversary Games in 2013 to salute their hero

And now? He is still. He has never been banned, he has never failed a drugs test, the allegations against his coach are yet to touch him, directly. There are plenty ready to vouch for Farah, to claim he is the innocent party, unjustly tainted by association. Yet it isn’t good. This isn’t good.

There are 16 witnesses making allegations against Salazar, his coach, with tales of testosterone and clear vials.

There are two confirmed missed tests, aberrations from a time when Farah’s standing in the sport was improving, rapidly. And there is an explanation around a muffled doorbell ring that suggests, far from being wrongly besmirched, Farah was treated quite leniently by the authorities.

He was at home in Teddington when the testers called in 2011. His house was not huge. They rang the doorbell, which he said was hard to hear from his bedroom. Simms made a video attempting to prove this. And, of course, it is a plausible explanation. A person doesn’t always hear the bell at home, or even a knock at the door.

Mo Farah's agent, Ricky Simms, made a video inside the athlete's house in Teddington, London to try to show why he failed to hear the doorbell from his upstairs bedroom (above) when the drug testers called in 2011

After entering the house Simms filmed as he went up some stairs to the first-floor living/trophy room (above) where the doorbell sound was clearly audible

Simms then climbed some more stairs and passed an altitude machine (above) before entering Farah’s second-floor bedroom. The doorbell is barely audible

Yet testers don’t ring once and depart. They hang around, for the allotted hour the athlete is supposed to be available. They knock. They try again.

The reason Simms was so impassioned in making Farah’s case, is that holing up in a room that made it difficult to hear the bell might fall into the dangerous category of evasion.

Without doubt, this second missed test could have been taken further had Farah’s explanation not been indulged. The second missed test wasn’t discounted, but nor was it played up into something more serious.

For now, there are the memories. Farah, out on his own on Super Saturday, Farah, holding off a pack of menacing rivals to complete a double in the 5,000 metres, Farah and Usain Bolt swapping poses, the Mobot and the archer. The Olympic Stadium was never louder, more impassioned than for Farah’s second gold. It was as charged as Sydney was for Cathy Freeman or Ian Thorpe. That noise, that fervour, is our legacy. This was the best we could be.

An overjoyed Farah crosses the line to win the 5,000m title to complete a long-distance Olympic double

Farah and Usain Bolt share a moment during medal presentations during the euphoria of London 2012

‘A missed test doesn’t mean you are doping,’ said Olympic medallist Kelly Sotherton. ‘It doesn’t make you a drugs cheat.’

But there was a caveat. ‘If you make a mistake once, most athletes learn from it,’ she said.

rank_31.title: Olympic Stadium costs rise by whopping £35m as West Ham prepare to move in... but club will only pay £15m of £272m total
rank_31.text:
The cost of converting the Olympic Stadium into a new home for West Ham has risen to £272million, rocketing the overall cost of the project to £701m.

A 'fixed' conversion fee of £154m was originally agreed by London Legacy Development Corporation with constructor Balfour Beatty, but a rise in costs to £189.9m was announced in October and it has now emerged the final figure is even higher.

In the bid for the London 2012 Games, the Olympic Stadium cost was put at £280m, but the final construction price tag was £429m.

Scroll down to video

West Ham's newly-appointed manager Slaven Bilic pictured at their soon-to-be Olympic Stadium home

The move overseen by West Ham co-owners David Sullivan (left), David Gold (right) and vice-chairman Karren Brady (centre) has cost over £118million more than was first expected from Upton Park

West Ham will move into the 54,000-seater venue at Stratford for the start of the 2016/2017 season, and will pay a contribution of some £15m as well as a £2.5m annual rent on a 99-year lease, while British Athletics are entitled to host 20 days per annum.

The Olympic Stadium will boast the world's largest cantilevered roof, coming at a cost of some £193.9m, with some 21,000 moveable seats. It will hold the Sainsbury's Anniversary Games next month as well as Rugby World Cup matches in September and the Race of Champions motorsport event at the multi-use arena.

The breakdown of the funding showed some £148.8m in 2010 from corporate social responsibility settlement and 'income generated on the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park through land sales and profits from venues'. Newham Council contributed £40m, the Government £25m and UK Athletics £1m. There was £38.7m from the Games Public Sector Funding Package and £3.5m from the London Marathon Charitable Trust.

Local school clubs will be given year-round access to the new floodlit 400 metres track, with a training and education centre in the stadium, which will offer up to 100,000 free tickets every year for Newham residents at West Ham matches.

Chief executive of the LLDC David Goldstone is confident the commercial deals in place will mean the Olympic Stadium should not require further public money.

'We have invested in transforming a temporary athletics venue into a permanent world-class multi-use arena that has a secure and long-term sustainable future. This has required a significant amount of work and innovative engineering solutions,' Goldstone said.

'Alongside the transformation work the deals signed with British Athletics and West Ham United and the appointment of a stadium operator ensures the stadium will pay its way and not require any continuing subsidy from the taxpayer.'

London Major Boris Johnson believes the final project is the best outcome.

The vast Olympic Stadium was so iconic during the successful London 2012 Games

He said in a statement: 'A very bad call was made when those in charge at the time backed a stadium construction plan that would leave the Olympic Park with a much smaller, mouldering and tumbleweed ridden arena following the Games,' Johnson said.

'Following that plan would have literally torn the heart out of the park and put at risk the incredible economic regeneration we are now seeing in east London.

'Our remedy offered long-term sustainable investment in order to protect an iconic stadium that Londoners took to their hearts, and which is now set to be home to almost every conceivable sport, concert or community event for decades to come.

'We've created a knockout venue that will drive and sustain thousands of jobs, where we've ensured that a hefty share of the profits will be paid back into the taxpayers coffers and which provides a genuine Olympic legacy for our city.'

rank_14.title: Tessa Jowell says London Olympics 2012 legacy has been 'squandered'
rank_14.text:
Sport England figures show number of over 16s participating in sport at least once a week is 15.49million, down from 15.89million in October 2012

claimed we are 'back where we started in 2002'

The chance to build a London 2012 legacy of wider participation in sport has been 'squandered', according to former Olympics minister Dame Tessa Jowell.

The London mayoral candidate, part of the team that helped secure the 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games for the capital, branded the coalition government 'wicked and negligent'.

While the regeneration of east London had been a success, cuts to school sports programmes had left grass-roots participation 'back where we started in 2002', she said.

Scroll down for video

Tessa Jowell said the chance to build an Olympic legacy of wider participation in sport has been 'squandered'

Tessa Jowell, part of the team that helped secure the 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games for London, branded the coalition government 'wicked and negligent'

Sport England's latest figures from April 2015 suggested the number of people over 16 participating in sport at least once a week stood at 15.49million, down from 15.89million in October 2012

Sport England's latest figures from April 2015 suggested the number of people over 16 participating in sport at least once a week stood at 15.49 million, down from 15.89 million in October 2012.

A total of 1.4 million more people have been playing sport since the first year of Sport England's Active People Survey 2005/06, when the Olympics were secured.

Dame Tessa told the Guardian: 'Instead of a generation of children being transformed by sport, a generation of children have been robbed of the chance to discover a sport they're really good at.

'We were on track. It was absolutely, wholly and solely their fault. It was going to be delivered. We were on course to deliver it as the figures make absolutely clear. Whenever I think about it, it makes me furious that this opportunity was squandered. My fury is on behalf of all those who were starting secondary schools five years ago.

Last month Boris Johnson, pictured with Jowell in 2012, defended the Government's record in the Commons

'I hope this is a huge stain on their consciences. When we get to Tokyo (in 2020) I think it likely we'll be back to half our medalists being from independent schools. It doesn't mean they're great athletes.

'There are fewer people now playing sport. It is on the conscience of those ministers.'

In her interview with the Guardian she pointed the finger at Michael Gove, who was education secretary from 2010 to 2014, for cutting £162m in ringfenced funding for school sport, calling the move a 'small decision with huge consequences'.

Last month Boris Johnson defended the Government's record in the Commons, saying all major venues had been or were set to be opened to the public and the private investment in London which followed the games had ensured 'a phenomenal legacy'.

Lord Coe, the chairman of London 2012, believes a wider view needs to be taken.

Lord Coe (right), chairman of London 2012, believes a wider view needs to be taken to improve participation

Writing in the Daily Telegraph, he said: 'There is much wailing and gnashing of teeth whenever Sport England releases its latest participation figures. I believe there is little value in looking at the figures in six-monthly chunks, let us look across 10-year cycles.

'Pre-2005 there is little doubt sport participation was declining and had been for a long time, particularly amongst young people. Since bidding for the Games, that trend has reversed. In the past 10 years of the Active People survey, 1.4 million more people are doing sport at least once a week.

rank_34.title: Usain Bolt will return to Olympic Stadium where he won three gold medals, at Anniversary Games
rank_34.text:
Anniversary Games will be held in London to extend Olympic legacy

Bolt is preparing for the World Championships in Beijing in August

Usain Bolt will be back at London's Olympic Stadium this summer after agreeing to run the 100m at the Anniversary Games at the end of the month.

The world's fastest man will return to the scene of his 2012 triumphs, when he won gold in the 100m, 200m and 4x100m relay, in what is a significant coup for British Athletics.

The Jamaican star has pulled out of recent Diamond League races in Lausanne and Paris, but is set to run on British soil as he tests his fitness ahead of the World Championships in Beijing in August.

Usain Bolt will be back at London's Olympic Stadium after agreeing to run the 100m at the Anniversary Games

Bolt has been convinced to return to London for the Anniversary Games after recent UK income tax changes

'London is a special place where I love to compete and I am looking forward to the Sainsbury's Anniversary Games on July 24,' he said.

'I have great memories of competing in the Olympic Stadium in the summer of 2012 and in the previous Grand Prix meets in London.

'The British fans are always great and I expect there will also be a lot of Jamaican fans in the stadium.

'It will be amazing to put on another great show for them under the floodlights on the Friday night.'

Bolt ran at the 2013 Anniversary Games, but did not return last year when no tax break was offered

Bolt triumphed at the London Olympic's in 2012 after winning gold in the 100m, 200m and 4x100m relay

Chancellor George Osborne waived UK income tax for athletes based overseas in this week's budget; a move which was enough to entice Bolt to come back to London.

He declined an invitation to compete last year when the event was held in Glasgow because no tax break scheme was in place, although he did run at the Commonwealth Games in the city two weeks later, where competitors were granted tax exemption.

Bolt, 29, did not compete in the UK in 2010 or 2011 as non-resident athletes are liable for 50 per cent tax on their appearance fee, plus a proportion of their worldwide earnings.

The Jamaican has struggled this year and was forced to pull out of national trials with a knee injury

The Jamaican has struggled for form this season, failing to break 20 seconds for 200m or 10 seconds for 100m and did not run in his national trials two weeks ago.

But he remains the biggest draw in athletics and his presence in London will give a huge boost to event organisers, especially as they are struggling to sell tickets for the Friday night session of the three-day event.

Bolt will also avoid having to go head-to-head again the quickest man in the world so far this year, Justin Gatlin, ahead of the World Championships because Anniversay Games organisers have made it quite clear the American is not welcome at the meeting owing to his two previous failed drugs tests.

rank_95.title: Karren Brady took over Olympic Stadium in a deal financed by the taxpayer
rank_95.text:
On a balmy evening in August, the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park echoes to the shrieks of joyriders on the Shark Bite rollercoaster and children frolicking excitedly in the dancing fountains.

Families share picnics and pose for selfies against the backdrop of the iconic stadium where Jessica Ennis-Hill and Mo Farah triumphed on that euphoric night three years ago.

They should take their souvenir photographs and enjoy the easy ambience while they can. The park won’t be the same for much longer.

In a few weeks’ time, preparations will begin for the Olympic stadium to be handed over to its new tenant, West Ham United Football Club, and it will be transformed into a brash Premier League citadel, packed from August to May with 54,000 rowdy fans.

The club’s owners, sex industry tycoons David Gold and David Sullivan, describe the makeover that will precede their four-mile migration from their antiquated ground in Upton Park as the ‘West Hamification’ process.

Scroll down for video

Victors: David Gold, Lady Brady and David Sullivan pictured at the Olympic Stadium

Having been converted for football at a cost to the taxpayer of £257 million, with the club paying just £15 million, the venue that witnessed British Olympic history being made will be daubed with the team’s claret and blue colours and the logos of such sponsors as online bookmakers Betway.

In the West Stand, there will be a ‘hospitality and entertainment experience’ called Club London, where the wealthier fans and celebrities can quaff champagne and nibble canapes and watch matches without having to rub shoulders with the hoi-polloi.

By paying between £60 and £499, supporters can even purchase granite stones inscribed with their names and slogans declaring their undying loyalty to the club — ‘Bob and Betty: True Hammers For Ever’ perhaps — that will form part of a huge mosaic which is to be laid beside the stadium.

Yet this garish makeover of this hallowed sporting venue is not the most troubling aspect of the controversial decision to lease the Olympic stadium to West Ham.

What concerns many is the extraordinarily favourable financial deal which was wrung from the London Legacy Development Corporation, the public body whose job it is to manage the transformation of the Olympic Park, by West Ham United’s vice-chairman Karren Brady.

Ms Brady, who is a long-time acolyte of pornographer Mr Sullivan, has — it must be noted — recently been ennobled by David Cameron, who also appointed her as a small business ambassador.

It was she who played a leading role in negotiating the terms of the 207-page leasehold contract between the club and the Legacy corporation; a document shrouded in such secrecy it arguably defies a fundamental tenet of democracy: the public’s right to know how its money is spent.

More than a decade ago, when London beat Paris, Madrid, Moscow and others to secure the 2012 Games, nobody envisaged the legacy would be to revive the fortunes of a near-bankrupt football club and further enrich two men who made millions by bringing sex shops and pornography to our High Streets.

Amid the rhetoric espoused by bid leader Lord Coe, among others, there was no mention of the benefits that might accrue to football for this would hardly have helped to sway the International Olympic Committee.

Instead, the mantra was that London 2012 would be a positive catalyst for social change, improving the lot of ordinary people in the most deprived part of the capital.

Central to this grandiose aim were the plans for the showpiece new stadium, designed specifically for athletics, in the expectation of enticing thousands to watch and participate in this Cinderella sport.

We must presume that the architects of London’s bid genuinely believed the arena could stage sufficient crowd-pulling athletics events to pay its way. If so, they were hopelessly naïve.

The other possibility is that they secretly knew that only a big-time football club could fill the new stadium, the cost of which spiralled from the original estimate of £280 million to £429 million, but did not dare to admit as much for fear that this would not chime with the Olympic spirit.

In which case, they were deeply disingenuous, for principle gave way to harsh economic reality long before the Games opened, as the stadium was put out to tender and, inevitably, football clubs muscled in.

Winner: Jessica Ennis-Hill celebrates gold at the London 2012 Olympic Games in London

After a bidding process more bitterly fought than the battle to stage the Olympics themselves, West Ham beat Tottenham Hotspur and East London minnows Leyton Orient to win the concession.

To Andrew Boff, Tory leader in the London Assembly, the plan put forward by Spurs (demolish the stadium and build one designed for football) would have been the best option for taxpayers because it would have spared them the £257 million conversion cost.

Furthermore, he argues, while the stadium is described as iconic, with its unlovely, Meccano- like structure ‘it has little architectural merit’.

As Mr Boff says, it would have taken a brave politician to order the setting for our finest sporting spectacle to be bulldozed.

However, he described the West Ham deal to me this week as ‘incredibly suspect’; not because he suspects for one minute it was in any way corrupt but because he believes it was concocted to ensure the stadium was preserved despite the vast cost, thus sparing the blushes of those who championed it.

This, needless to say, is not a view shared by the Legacy corporation and West Ham.

They insist that the deal, which will give the club a 99-year lease but allow for other occasional sporting and entertainment events, with a share of the profits being paid into the public purse, represents very good value for the taxpayer.

‘A Premier League football tenant will drive millions of visitors to Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park, maintaining a global profile that will attract many income-raising opportunities,’ the Legacy corporation said in a statement this week.

West Ham, for its part, claimed the move would create 700 jobs, bring a million more people (its fans) to the Park each year and ‘add value to any sponsorship and commercial agreements relating to the stadium which the public purse will benefit from’.

Presumably this covers the naming rights to the stadium, which is expected to be rechristened, doubtless to advertise some giant foreign enterprise, in the near future.

In short, the club argues that if it wasn’t moving in, the Olympic stadium would become a loss- making white elephant.

The fireworks erupt at the Olympic Opening Ceremony during London 2012

Perhaps. The big question is: what will the taxpaying public gain in return for stumping up virtually the entire cost of building and reconfiguring the stadium? That will amount to £701 million by the time West Ham takes occupancy.

After pressure from concerned parties, the weighty contract documenting the deal was recently released under the Freedom of Information Act.

Yet so many of its clauses have been redacted that, in the words of Richard Hunt of the Charlton Athletic Supporters Trust (which vehemently opposes the deal because of the detrimental effect it could have on other London football clubs such as theirs), there is ‘a sea of black ink’ covering sections of the text.

The trust has complained to the Information Commissioner about this secrecy, requested by the Legacy corporation on the grounds that revealing contractual details would be commercially damaging. A ruling is expected later this month.

However, according to the sports promoter Barry Hearn, who, as owner until last year of Leyton Orient FC fought against West Ham’s tenancy of the Olympic stadium, we already know enough about the arrangement to see how the taxpayer is being fleeced.

This is the worst-negotiated deal since the North American Indians gave up their land for a handful of trinkets Sports promoter, Barry Hearn

‘This is the worst-negotiated deal since the North American Indians gave up their land for a handful of trinkets,’ Hearn told me this week. Judging by the generous terms set out in the contract’s few un-redacted passages, it is difficult to argue.

It states that the London Legacy Development Corporation will foot West Ham’s bills for a wide range of services normally paid for by football clubs, from match-day security to ticketing, pitch maintenance, lighting and heating bills, and even the maintenance of fans’ lavatories. Astonishingly, the publicly funded landlords will even pick up the tab for the nets and the corner-flags!

By the way, West Ham could afford to splash out £33 million on new players last year and, despite the confines of its old ground, it declared a pre-tax profit of £15.3 million.

The Legacy Corporation and club would have us believe this generosity is par for the course. ‘If you hire a badminton court at the local leisure centre you wouldn’t expect to provide your own net,’ is how it was blithely explained to me this week.

However, the deal Baroness Brady has secured appears to be one of the greatest contractual coups in sporting history. Though it will transform West Ham’s future at the stroke of a pen, Barry Hearn believes that the club is effectively getting the stadium free.

This is because the annual rent, believed to be no more than £2.5 million (less should the club be relegated from the Premier League), will be more than offset by the costs to be paid by the Legacy corporation, he says. Then there are the millions West Ham will receive every year from corporate hospitality. Other reports suggest it will get a slice of the catering revenues, too.

Examining those parts of the contract we are permitted to see, I also found a clause that hints at lucrative rights West Ham has won. As it will run the stadium’s only merchandise store, it will not only be authorised to sell football-related products but clothes, souvenirs and memorabilia for the IAAF World Athletics Championships to be staged there in 2017.

Presumably this will apply to other major events and the club will no doubt demand a healthy cut of the profits.

An aerial view across London and of the Olympic Park in Stratford, featuring the Olympic Stadium

However, it is the many clauses which are obliterated by black ink that should worry us most, for who knows what other little sweeteners the astute First Lady of Football has elicited for her paymasters?

Though Gold and Sullivan have vowed never to sell West Ham, insisting it will be their children’s legacy, the undeniable possibility remains that they will be tempted by the riches of some Middle Eastern sheik or Russian oligarch.

After all, as Barry Hearn says, the Qataris already own a sizeable chunk of the Olympic village and the stadium ‘would complete the jigsaw’. They toured the stadium before the Games and were interested in naming rights.

On the back of the stadium deal, analysts say West Ham’s value has soared at least fourfold, from £105 million in 2010, when the two businessman bought their controlling stake, to more than £400 million.

Were they to cash in their chips, what proportion of the sale price (if any) could be clawed back by the public? This is one of many secrets contained in the contract which patently ought to be uncovered.

Chris Bryant, Shadow Secretary for culture, media and sport, suggests the deal might be so loaded in West Ham’s favour that it breaches European Commission rules, since it could hand the club an unfair, state-aided advantage over competitors in the football business.

For instance, because West Ham’s stadium costs will be so low, they will be able to reduce seating prices and ‘dump’ thousands of tickets (100,000 are to be handed to Newham Council each season for distribution among the community) thus attracting thousands of new fans who might otherwise have chosen to watch, say, Arsenal.

Nevertheless, Sullivan, 66, who began life on a Cardiff council estate and is now said to be worth £850 million, and Gold, 79, who as a boy peddled buttons on the streets of West Ham and has built a £350 million fortune, are convinced that the relocation is ‘a game-changer’, to quote the club’s website.

They can see it catapulting the team they have supported since their East End boyhood to the summit of world football alongside the likes of Manchester United.

The pair have further lined their pockets by selling Upton Park to property developers Galliard Homes.

It is not known how much they received, though the ground was valued in recent accounts at more than £70 million.

Galliard has submitted plans to build 838 apartments there, just six per cent of which would be ‘affordable housing’ within the price range of ordinary East Enders.

Newham’s Mayor, Sir Robin Wales, has warned Galliard that is ‘totally unacceptable’ but it is feared that most of the flats will be so expensive they will be bought by overseas investors.

Again, this is hardly in keeping with the promises made in the Olympic legacy.

There are other key players in this darkly intriguing tale, prominent among them London Mayor Boris Johnson, who was in many ways the public face of the Games, who has ignored the misgivings of fellow Tories in the Assembly to give the secret deal his blessing.

Barry Hearn believes that if the censor’s black ink is removed, Boris’s stance will be proved so ill-judged that it could even damage his prime ministerial ambitions.

Meanwhile, we can but wonder how taxpayer-funded goalposts replaced the lofty goals that were to have been the legacy of London 2012.

rank_132.title: Karren Brady hits back at Olympic Stadium critics and says West Ham took over the house nobody wanted
rank_132.text:
Karren Brady is standing on the touchline of what, next season, will be West Ham’s pitch when she cuts to the heart of the matter.

‘You see,’ she says, looking around an arena now readying itself for the Rugby World Cup, ‘anyone could have bought this. Leyton Orient, the Qataris, anyone. But nobody saw it, nobody saw the potential here. So roll back that movie without West Ham. Taxpayers’ money would have poured into a big hole, been concreted over and never seen again.

‘Now the stadium is nearly finished, everyone recognises what is here and says it’s a steal. But it wasn’t a steal when we were doing the negotiations, because where was the queue of rival buyers? Without West Ham this would have been pulled down. It was going to be 25,000 with no roof.

Scroll down for video

Karren Brady speaks to Sportsmail's Martin Samuel about West Ham's move to the Olympic Stadium

Brady has spearheaded West Ham's move from Upton Park to the Olympic Stadium, scheduled for 2016

Brady believes that West Ham were the first organisation to realise the potential of moving into the stadium

West Ham will look to fill the Olympic Stadium with 54,000 supporters for each home league encounter

‘And what would have happened then? Who would have come to that stadium? That’s a legacy? Tottenham just wanted to flatten it and start again. So no Olympic Stadium at all. This is going to be an asset, a national asset. We shouldn’t have to keep justifying ourselves.’

But they do. Each week a fresh guardian of taxpayers’ money pontificates over West Ham’s deal for the Olympic Stadium. From failed bidders to vested interests, all get a say. Brady stands accused of doing too well for her employers. And everyone ignores that bottom line. Without West Ham, what? A miserably small, rain-sodden concrete bowl, with scant relation in size or emotional charge to the site of London’s Olympics. It would be as if the Games never happened.

It is a bright August afternoon: school holidays, yet the Olympic Park is dead. Nobody visits The Orbit monument. The European Hockey Championships are taking place at Eton Manor, to a shrug. Of the 16 sessions, just one is sold out. Deserted, forgotten, the Park needs its anchor tenant. No Olympic legacy is created without one.

The Aquatic Centre in Athens is weed-filled and dry. The iconic Birds Nest in Beijing has moonlighted as a Segway racetrack. Even Barcelona’s Montjuic hosts events sporadically. In one of the greatest tourist destinations in Europe, it often stands empty.

With a small capacity and no roof in a wet country, London’s Olympic Stadium would have quietly expired. So if Brady got the deal of the century, as is suggested — West Ham’s end of the conversion is £15million, the government pay £257m — where were the other entrepreneurs jostling to get in on the act? How come a mid-table Premier League football club had the only vision worth pursuing?

West Ham got the Olympic Stadium twice. Once to buy outright, later as anchor tenants. It was the London Legacy Development Corporation that decided not to go with the first option in which West Ham would have picked up the lion’s share of costs.

The Olympic Stadium is currently being prepared to host games for the upcoming Rugby World Cup

France, New Zealand, Ireland and South Africa will all take the pitch during the Rugby World Cup

Two construction workers look out over the iconic stadium, one wearing a West Ham-branded high-vis jacket

An ice bath has already been installed in the dressing room ahead of West Ham's arrival

Brady admits that some of the public are against what she calls the 'West Hamification' of the stadium

Claret and blue tiles line the home side's shower room in tribute to the club's famous home kit

‘That was the initial deal,’ says Brady. ‘The LLDC recognised they had made a mistake by not working out the legacy, saw all the other Olympic Stadiums that were left to rot and decided something permanent had to happen.

‘Our choice was to buy and convert. We would have paid for the floodlights, the roof, the seats, the toilets, the turnstiles — everything would have been down to us. We could easily have funded £200m, particularly with the new television deal and we would have kept all the revenue, giving us a calendar year of income.

‘We won the vote 11-0 and then they changed their minds. They wanted tenants instead. So they collapsed the old process and started a new one, which is where we are now. We came out unanimously as the best bid that time, too. So I don’t think the criticism is fair.

‘There were no sweetheart deals. It was me, on my own, against Allen & Overy, the government and all their advisers. They had more lawyers, more government consultants and officials than I have ever seen in my life and there was one seat on the other side, for me. But I knew they needed a football club and, ultimately, nothing would happen in the Park without us.

West Ham's presence could stop the stadium becoming running into disrepair like the Athens aquatics centre

The iconic Bird's Nest stadium in Beijing has a second role hosting segway competitions

‘People think we got something for nothing in that room, but we didn’t. I can’t be the buyer and the seller. I can’t negotiate against myself, my employers and the West Ham fans. My job is to exceed their expectations so when they walk in they say, “You know what, she was right. We had to move here”. And then they don’t care that we don’t own it, or that it is ours for 23 days a year.

‘And when people are spilling out into the park, or going to the athletics or the hockey because we’re cross-promoting and they think of this as home and feel an attachment they didn’t previously, and when there are concerts and the flats are full and this is part of the national fabric, that’s the day I’m looking forward to.

‘Football is on the up right now so this gets called the deal of the century. But West Ham aren’t getting rich because of the stadium. West Ham were getting rich anyway. The television money comes to us whether we’re in the worst ground or the best, the brand value is building because of the success of the football club.

‘Sometimes I feel like we took over a house that nobody wanted, did it up and made a fortune. Is that lucky? Is that the deal of the century or did you have a bit of foresight and make it work?’

On the pitch, West Ham are eager to avoid relegation to the Championship ahead of their stadium move

West Ham have 17 home Premier League games remaining before they leave their home for the Olympic Park

Back-to-back home defeats have raised the dark thought that West Ham could arrive as a Championship club, still needing to fill 54,000 seats against Huddersfield. It is the worst-case scenario, but just three games in Brady is not panicking yet. Her point remains that the Olympic Stadium would still have needed its tenant, regardless of short-term status.

‘Simply, without West Ham, this place would have been demolished and the Park would be done,’ she continues. ‘If this is going to get the community usage, it needs a spark, a lot of events, and that’s why a football tenant is the most important because it is our supporters who will fill it and bring the income that pays for it to be maintained.

‘We’re here for 99 years, not one season – and if you took our financial commitment over that time, you could build two Olympic Stadiums for the money.

‘We are leaving a successful stadium that was ours for 365 days a year, giving up income streams, sharing catering revenue, sharing naming rights. Premier League football hits 4.4 billion people around the world. We bring that audience in. What would the naming rights be worth without West Ham?

‘We have to build a whole new club infrastructure, offices, a club shop, install new software, new facilities — all of that is going to cost around £7m on top of what we paid. And then people think we’re in it just to sell up. But every angle was covered. Obviously, West Ham’s worth will increase if we are successful here.

‘The LLDC were worried our owners would have an incentive to sell. But we had the club valued in 2013 when the deal was done and the government receives a massive slice of any profit made on our shares after that. Of course, with the new TV deal, West Ham’s value has risen anyway. But the government still gets its slice, even on stuff that has nothing to do with the new stadium.’

That is the fear, of course. A couple of wide boys on the make, David Sullivan and David Gold — West Ham’s co-owners, with their backgrounds in pornography and the Ann Summers chain — seizing this national treasure and as good as knocking it out from the back of a lorry.

Once West Ham have their 54,000-capacity ground, it is argued, they will sell their shares at a huge profit. Lovely jubbly.

David Gold, one of West Ham's co-owners, has played a key role in the club securing access to the venue

David Sullivan owns West Ham with Gold and will oversee the move from Upton Park to the Olympic Stadium

‘Look at it another way,’ Brady says. ‘You’ve got Goodwood, you’ve got Ascot, all these institutions that are leaving British ownership, and we don’t like it. So here are two businessmen, who pay all their tax in the UK and have given personal guarantees for every penny we owe. We can no longer borrow against our ground as an asset, so our owners have underwritten this move, personally.’

I say maybe there is distaste about Sullivan and Gold’s past. That people would have been happier if reputable folk from the spotless environs of the City had done the deal instead.

‘I don’t think owning a chain of underwear shops like David Gold makes you a porn baron,’ she counters. ‘And I think Fifty Shades of Grey is a bit racier than some of the stuff David Sullivan was involved in during his twenties. It shouldn’t taint you forever. David’s early business life shouldn’t define him.

CAPACITY INCREASE? West Ham have been so buoyed by the sale of season tickets at the new Olympic Stadium that the club are already discussing increasing capacity to 66,000. The expansion would make West Ham’s new ground the biggest of any club in London, eclipsing Arsenal’s Emirates Stadium and Tottenham’s new facility next to White Hart Lane. Despite erratic form at the start of their final season at Upton Park, West Ham’s owners are greatly encouraged by the take-up of tickets at the Olympic venue. They will move in at the start of next season, 2016-17. And with the current capacity at 54,000, there is the potential to fill in space around the top of the arena with another 12,000 seats. Karren Brady, West Ham vice-chair, said this is something the club are already considering. ‘We always knew this was a possibility and it would certainly seem the interest is there,’ she said. ‘We have to look at the logistics of it because these would be the seats furthest from the pitch, so we have to make sure they are worth having. There is no point sticking someone in a corner with a poor view. But if the sight lines are still good, we could fit in 66,000. It’s a very exciting prospect.’

‘We don’t like losing Ascot but when two British taxpayers come along and show a bit of vision and ambition, we don’t like that, either.’

And there is vision in the way the Olympic Stadium has been remodelled. The way the floodlights have been inverted in the new roof structure, the largest cantilevered structure of its kind in Europe.

The Great Britain lounge will permanently celebrate Olympic and other sporting successes, with the World Cup winners’ medals of Bobby Moore, Geoff Hurst and Martin Peters — all owned by West Ham — finally removed from vaults and placed on display.

People forget the elitist nature of the old stadium. There were 400 VIP seats, exclusively used by IOC members. Event tickets cost a fortune. A personal recollection? On August 10, 2012, my wife took one of our sons to the athletics. We paid £900 for the privilege of watching the biggest cheat of the Games, Asli Cakir Alptekin, win the women’s 1,500 metres. She has now returned her gold medal and is serving an eight-year ban, for a second doping offence.

So let’s not pretend that handing the stadium over to the tainted sport of athletics would be any less controversial in today’s climate. As for tickets, the main complaint appears to be that West Ham will make them too cheap.

‘I’ve heard we will be dumping free tickets everywhere to fill this place,’ Brady adds. ‘We won’t. If we do that, nobody will value a seat at West Ham. The Charlton Athletic Supporters Club are complaining, but Charlton can’t sell out. They have empty seats. So it’s not as if we are taking Charlton supporters. It’s that there are not enough of them in the first place. And that’s not our fault.

‘I think it’s quite insulting to Charlton fans to paint them as so fickle that they’ll buy a season ticket for a rival club, just because we’ve got a new ground. No Charlton fan is going to wake up on the first morning of next season and think, “Oh, I’m West Ham now”.’

It is CAST who have complained to the Information Commissioner about the redacted passages in West Ham’s contract, particularly specific figures detailing the split between the club and the LLDC.

‘They think it was all underhand, but there is a reason for the blanks,’ Brady insists. ‘This is a multi- purpose stadium. Other people will want to use it. If all they have to do is open West Ham’s contract and see the figures, that’s the end of the negotiation, isn’t it? The LLDC have no position.’

Brady, pictured with Gold and Sullivan in 2011, says the move will allow a regeneration of the area to take place

We watch a tractor with a handy piece of equipment erect rugby posts at each end. France are due here for their Pool D game with Romania on September 23. New Zealand, Ireland, Italy and South Africa will also visit — and the World Cup’s third place play-off will be the stadium’s final act before conversion begins in readiness for West Ham’s arrival in 2016. That is when it will look like West Ham’s home: claret and blue seats and the name above the door.

‘Some people don’t like what we call the “West Hamification” of the stadium,’ Brady says, ‘but it has got to look like our home or our fans are not going to get behind it. And they have got to do that for it to work.

‘I feel a huge sense of personal responsibility that I am part of the delivery programme here. We’ve made a promise to fill this place and bring the Park to life and we will do exactly that. And of all the clubs that could represent Britain, I think West Ham is that club.

‘I don’t think we’re fleecing British taxpayers because we’re taxpayers, too. We will ensure this stadium is full, that jobs are created and regeneration takes place. And I can say that because I’m the one doing it.’

rank_88.title: West Ham's Olympic Stadium move means we still have a home for heroes, but it doesn't sit there doing nothing for 50 weeks
rank_88.text:
A tour around the Olympic Stadium with Karren Brady sparked this week's debate. Read it here. Have West Ham mugged the taxpayer or have West Ham helped save a national treasure? I know what I think. You decide.

And like my dreams they fade and die… King Sandro, London.

No idea the point of that post, mate. But here's the original.

The British tax payers, Lotto players and football fans are being ripped off by this decision to allow West Ham supporters a cheap way to watch their club. Charge West Ham a decent amount to have this ground on lease and set a weekly cut of gate share, which they would never have got otherwise. Alf2, Sunderland.

West Ham will pay £2.5million annually to use the stadium for 23 days, and give up the lion's share of catering and naming rights. If they had to share gate revenue, too, and pay more than roughly £108,500 per match, the terms would have become uncompetitive and the deal would have been lost. Then the taxpayer really would be getting nothing for something. As for Lotto players, it's a choice. Don't buy one if you don't like it.

I've always wanted a ticket to the Olympic Stadium. Looks like West Ham will have at least 20,000 spare every game. Devil Dance, United Kingdom.

And amid the stupidity, a serious point is by accident made. Here a bit of the conversation with Karren Brady that didn't make it into the column, to clarify. 'A lot of people didn't get the chance to see the stadium during the Olympics. Next season, as away fans, they can. I'm sure they will, too. That has a knock-on effect in the area, from the shops to the hotels, and particularly the Park. This is the catalyst for everything that goes on here – over the season there will be one million people engaging in the area. We will cross-promote events – hockey, swimming, athletics, our supporters will get offered deals to go to those events, those sports that need a wider audience.' I know you were trying to knock it, but see what I did there?

As for the Charlton fans who keep piping up: isn't this the club that laid on coaches to take fans from Gillingham to The Valley for games? Jitman, London.

Indeed it is, Jitman. And still does, in fact. Their website confirms this. 'The club continues to run the popular Valley Express service, bringing in supporters old and new to home matches from dozens of pick-up points across Kent and Sussex.' So by new customers, one presumes they mean people who previously didn't support Charlton Athletic. And as these pick-up points include the home of Football League teams Brighton, Gillingham and Crawley Town, and National League teams Margate, Dover, Maidstone and Eastbourne, it does seem rather hypocritical to accuse West Ham of trying to poach Charlton fans simply by existing in a bigger stadium. It's not as if extra ferries are being laid on from Woolwich. Anyway, Charlton have never been considered rivals to West Ham. London is the only city in England whose clubs divide on the points of a compass – north, south, east and west. Charlton are a south London club, West Ham from east London. Folk in provincial cities might find this surprising, but there is about as much chance of a south Londoner veering towards West Ham as there is of a bloke in Sheffield deciding to support Leeds.

Let us have an interview with Barry Hearn now. Tom Graham, Coventry.

Yes, he can talk us through the times he discussed moving Leyton Orient to Basildon and Harlow. And explain why, if Orient wanted the stadium so much, they were not part of the final bidding process for tenancy; or the initial bidding process to buy outright for that matter.

Karren Brady speaks to Martin Samuel at the Olympic Stadium about West Ham's move there next season

Brady spoke candidly about West Ham's move to the stadium and her answers prompted this debate

The fact is the London taxpayer was forced to pay for this stadium or face prison. The London taxpayer wouldn't have had to pay £280m for conversion if Tottenham had got the stadium, as the club would have paid it. That's what needs an explanation. If they weren't going to go with Tottenham then whoever rented it should have paid much more money to do so. PJ, London.

Actually the taxpayer (not the London taxpayer, because the stadium is nationally funded) has to pay taxes or face prison (not a specific tax for the Olympic Stadium) anyway. What did you think, mate? If Tottenham bought it someone was going to knock on your day and give you a 10 quid rebate? 'There you go, son, that tenner was for converting the Olympic Stadium into a multi-purpose national venue. We don't need it now. Don't spent it all at once.' Is that what happened when they sold the Millennium Dome? Because I must have been out when the government popped round with my fiver from that fiasco. As for your second point, a Mr Koopa will explain.

West Ham would have paid it too, if you had bothered to read the actual article. The problem was the LLDC decided not to sell the stadium and instead lease it out, so Tottenham withdrew. If there was more, indeed any, competition I'm sure the rent would have been higher. But there wasn't, so it was a case of either letting West Ham have it, at a rent that will amount to £198m eventually, plus a share of naming and catering revenue that will more than cover the conversion costs, or let it sit empty and have the taxpayers fund a rotting, empty bowl. Worked out great for the Millennium Dome, didn't it? Koopa, London.

Glad you mentioned the Dome, Koopa. We paid £789m for that, including huge maintenance costs when it stood idle, before the lease went to Meridian Delta and then AEG. They spent £600m developing it into the largest entertainment complex in Europe and sold the naming rights to O2 for £6m a year. Have you been lately? The venues, the restaurants, the catering, the shops, the residences, the events, the tickets – how long do you think before they get their money back? And nobody in our government had the brains to manage that aspect of the development. We have the freehold, with a 993-year lease now owned by Trinity College, Cambridge, as part of its property portfolio, so our part of it is in essence a gigantic loss, minus 15 per cent of AEG's net profit on the site every year. In year one, even with extra opening costs, the O2 made a pre-tax profit of £15.6m. So the government got back a sliver of £789m. By 2012, the site was returning £62.8m. And we sold that, don't forget. Meanwhile, when AEG went on the market that year and with the O2 complex included, the company was valued in the region of £4.5 billion. So if we had spent the £600m on further developing the site, and had managed it as well as AEG, we'd have all of the money back, from that and the original project, in between 20 and 25 years. Instead? We may break even around 2094. So the idea that selling saves the taxpayer money, long-term, is fallacy. Selling chokes the income stream and that is the only way the money can ever be recouped. It just takes time.

I think Leyton Orient would have liked to get it but they were quickly ruled out. Brum, West Midlands.

With proper foresight Leyton Orient should have been awarded the hockey stadium, with drop-in pitches, grass and synthetic, to accommodate the two sports. I wrote this at the time, but vision is not our strong point, I'm afraid.

Remember a few years ago when West Ham played Reading in what was pretty much a promotion decider and they were still advertising tickets the night before the game because they couldn't sell out? David, Reading.

March 31, 2012. Yes, I remember the match, David. West Ham lost 4-2. But the gate was 33,350, so bigger than all Premier League attendances that day, bar two. Manchester City got 47,007 for the visit of Sunderland – mind you they were two points off the top – and Aston Villa attracted 34,740 for Chelsea, so 1,390 more than West Ham got for Reading. Interesting, though, that 47,000 at City – because nobody thought they would fill their new ground, either. But I feel clubs should think big. Maybe if there was more aspiration at Reading, you wouldn't be getting 16,547 for Milton Keynes Dons.

Abdoulaye Faye shrugs as Reading celebrate a win which moved them four points clear of West Ham in 2012

Sam Allardyce - more about him later - looks anguished during the loss, but his team went up via the play-offs

Why couldn't Orient share? It would make perfect sense. Southlondonsnumber1, London.

What, a club that got 4,949 for Stevenage Borough last week, in a ground with a 54,000 capacity? Yes, if you wanted them dead, it would.

Thank God for Brady and the Bongo Brothers saving the taxpayer a fortune. What's that? We are paying for everything? Oh. Rob, Hampshire.

It's not their job to save the taxpayer a fortune, Rob. That's what a government is for, if you are that way inclined politically.

West Ham were about to buy it till Tottenham and Orient kicked up a stink. We won the first bid then they called for a review on the process and the government changed it to a tenancy. Tottenham never intended getting it. Daniel Levy just used it as a bargaining tool to get favourable terms for their new stadium because the council became worried they would move out of Tottenham. Isn't a lot of the improved infrastructure included in their new stadium now subsidised as a result? Tottenham fans are just jealous because West Ham are close to moving on before them. How many government funded schemes have my approval or have I had any use from anyway? Boom Town, London.

Indeed. And here's The Observer's take – dated March 22, 2015 – on the aftermath of Tottenham's failed Olympic stadium bid, and what Levy then managed to extract from London mayor Boris Johnson, and others, by way of compensation. 'Tottenham lost the bid, with Levy by all accounts furious with Johnson for leading him up a garden path, but only after the club's legal challenges had helped make less generous the deal offered by the public purse to the pornography magnates who run West Ham. Spurs made a further challenge, eventually called off, after which Johnson announced some funding to assist Tottenham, and the area around the stadium in particular. Tottenham also went back to Haringey to ask for a better deal on their planning permission: they wanted the requirement to build affordable housing, usual with proposed residential developments, to be removed. They wanted their Section 106 contribution, the money paid to help the public costs associated with private development, and which here included such things as upgrading nearby railway stations, reduced from £16.4m to £500,000. By now the riots had happened and Haringey, probably anxious to see something make progress in Tottenham, agreed to the reductions.' The figure from Johnson's office for infrastructure was £8.5m. So, yes, Tottenham clobbered the taxpayer for close to £25m, preying on the fear that followed the 2011 riots, while offering nothing in return.

Fantastic, unbelievable, stupendous deal for West Ham. It's so good it can be called legal robbery. Financially, the best deal on the table was from Tottenham and there is no denying that. I know Lord Coe wanted an athletics track retained – but let's be honest, who the hell watches athletics? Joe Mayo, London.

It's all in the timing, isn't it, Joe? As the heroes of the London Olympics' Super Saturday – Greg Rutherford, Mo Farah and Jessica Ennis-Hill – have all just won gold again in Beijing, can you imagine the hollow feeling if the stadium they graced in their own country was in ruins and all we had to show was a tarted-up Crystal Palace? Plenty of people watch athletics but not often enough for us to have a designated 54,000-capacity arena. That is why this is the best solution. We can still host major events, we still have a home fit for heroes – but it doesn't sit there doing nothing the other 50 weeks of the year. If we had knocked the Olympic Stadium down for a football club, right now – in this of all weeks – we would have looked like the most short-sighted nation in the world.

Mo Farah shows off his trademark finish to beat training partner Galen Rupp to victory in the 10,000m in 2012

Like Farah, Greg Rutherford continued his heroics after Super Saturday with victory in the Bird's Nest

I can never understand the Tottenham argument. They are not from East London. Their roots and heritage are in North London. How or why they wanted the stadium is beyond me. Andy H, Essex.

And I also remember the protests from their fans when it was proposed they moved to Stratford. Now half of them act like they've had something stolen from them. Equally, if Tottenham are so keen on helping the taxpayer, their owner, Joe Lewis, could start by paying his over here.

So Karren Brady showed Hagrid around the new stadium, did she? 'We'll have the best stadium in the whole of the championship.' Baz, Sunderland.

And Sunderland will have the second. Now bog off before I set the dragons on you.

David Sullivan and David Gold spent years at Birmingham City trying to get the council to fund a new stadium for them. Once it was never going to happen, they moved to West Ham and, guess what, they got a new stadium paid for by someone else. What an amazing coincidence. WeKnowTheScore, Birmingham.

Still, at least Birmingham have thrived since they left, eh?

West Ham versus Newcastle on Monday, September 14, kids get in for £1 because we struggle to sell out Upton Park. Where are these new fans waiting to fill this soulless bowl? The vast majority of fans don't want to leave the Boleyn. HHCD, Rochford.

That's just not true. The majority of West Ham fans that I know are behind, and very excited by, this move. And I don't think there will be much of a problem selling out in the first season. When the novelty wears off, if the team isn't doing well – that's when the hard work starts.

The government put themselves in a no-win situation as a lack of alternatives killed their negotiating position. What were they supposed to do with it after the 2012 Olympics anyway? We all loved the Olympics and it's a bit disingenuous to now cry foul. Steviejay99, Colchester.

I agree, Steve. Everyone now talks about the Olympics as if it was meant to be a property deal. It was the Olympics, we loved it, we had to build a stadium for it, but now it's over. So the only way forward is to continue finding ways to use it. This requires some extra conversion costs – because the project was poorly conceived initially – but the idea that the only reason for building was to stage some long-term property coup on behalf of the taxpayer is fatuous.

It will be a fantastic facility with absolutely no atmosphere. Fans miles from the pitch, and they'll never fill it. GR, Manchester.

Not necessarily. During my visit I deliberately walked up to the very top of the stadium and stood where the farthest fan will be. There were workmen on the other side of the pitch, so I had a fair idea of what players will look like from that distance, too. It wasn't bad. Certainly, I would imagine you are more divorced from proceedings in the equivalent seat at Old Trafford, which may be nearer the pitch but is considerably higher. As for the atmosphere, anyone who thinks it is impossible to create one in a football ground with a running track has never been to watch Napoli at home. Liveliest ground in Europe – and there's a running track. Bayern Munich didn't do too badly at their old place, either.

Napoli's San Paolo Stadium fills up ahead of a Coppa Italia match with Atalanta earlier this year

When full, the stadium is capable of breathtaking noise with fans creating an unparalleled atmosphere

Whoever took over the stadium would have wanted the same rates as West Ham. So they just got there first really. Where Am I 2, London.

Certainly, any tenant would expect the place to be habitable before moving in; and wouldn't expect to pay the full cost of that conversion or anything like it.

You cannot blame West Ham. If it's such a bad deal for the taxpayer then the blame lies at the government and dopey Boris Johnson's door. They have shirked their responsibility, which if you look at the Conservative party's history is typical, giving money away to their mates. You get what you vote for with the Conservative party. Longshanks, London.

Except the idiot politicians who failed to set the stadium up with a viable legacy – Ken Livingstone and Tessa Jowell – were both Labour. And the Conservative head of the London Assembly is a vocal opponent of the deal. I don't think this is a party political issue but if Karren Brady used her influence within the Conservative Party – and I don't feel she did – then that would be one of the advantages of having English owners. A bit hard for much of the Premier League to carry that sway when the clubs are owned in Russia, the Middle East and the United States.

Why didn't the Daily Mail send the journalist who wrote the original article containing all the questions that needed asking about this deal to do the interview, instead of Martin Samuel who has continually praised it in his column? Kevin, Rhyl.

Reading David Jones' recent article condemning the deal, it would seem he did speak to West Ham and the London Legacy Development Corporation. The LLDC are quoted, and there is a paragraph that begins 'West Ham, for its part, claimed…' which would suggest contact. So David chose what material he included in his piece – the Charlton Athletic Supporters Club, Barry Hearn, Andrew Boff, Conservative leader of the London Assembly – just as I choose what goes in my column. I'm sure Baroness Brady would have talked to him about the project, if asked. And the Mail did not send anybody to speak to Karren. Offered the chance to see the site for the first time, I took it. It was my interview, not a commission from the newspaper. As you say, I have been in favour of a football tenant since the Stadium was first built. So, by the way, has Sir Steven Redgrave. When London was awarded the Olympics, he said the Stadium should house Arsenal or Tottenham Hotspur, perhaps both, when the tournament was over. A pity the people in charge of the project – Livingstone, Jowell and Lord Coe – did not have his vision. As far back as February 2004, in The Times, I was advocating a football legacy and no mention of West Ham in that column. So this isn't a case of wanting a deal for West Ham. I wanted football to take on the Stadium because football is the only sport that could fill it. 'Athletics is opera to football's good musical. If the sport had to fund its own way, it would sink into a hole in the ground.' I stand by every word of that sentence and it was from a Times column over 11 years ago. To put that into perspective, this was in the charts. Nice bit of Dada for the video, too.

The biggest mistake was not incorporating legacy right from the start as they did for Manchester City and the Commonwealth Games stadium. Saltyseadog, South England.

Quite right. It would have been easy to design a multi-purpose stadium along the lines of the Stade de France but the politicians, and Lord Coe, wouldn't have it. Jowell will now run for London Mayor as if she helped organised a resounding triumph.

I'm a Hammer since the sixties and I hate this plastic monstrosity. The Boleyn Ground is magnetic and has character. They just want more corporate seats. This is all the about money and the prawn sandwich brigade. Wampum, Afghanistan.

Plastic monstrosity? What about the fake castles on the front facade at Upton Park? It looks like a lousy ride at Disneyland. And, yes, no doubt the owners want more corporate seats. Maybe you are one of the fans currently moaning that the club needs players. How many do you think can be bought with Kids For A Quid? And now, realists.

I've probably seen 1,000 games over Upton Park but I'm getting older, have moved away and don't go so much now. The young fans want this to happen and I'm delighted for them. To be honest, much of the old atmosphere went with introduction of all-seater stadiums same as everywhere else. The world has changed and West Ham need to move with the times. I can't wait to go and see the new place. Suns Out Guns Out, Ireland.

I have been going since the 1970s. The Chicken Run has gone, the North and South Banks have gone, the Boleyn lost all its charm for me when it became all-seater. The West Stand now makes it look lopsided, because we're not allowed to build the East Stand bigger. It was all local support when I started going, proper fans, but no one lives around the ground anyone, so it's unrecognisable. Walking up Green Street, sometimes you don't actually know you're in West Ham territory until you see the dodgy turrets. I'm in, because it can't be worse and a lot of clubs have made it work. I've been to the Emirates. They call it soulless but, to be honest, I can't remember Highbury being noisier. If the younger ones want this for West Ham, they will go and support it. I don't buy into the argument that you can't take your history. You can: history is the past, your memories, and you can take them anywhere. ICWHS, Stockholm.

I agree. I go to plenty of new grounds, but that doesn't mean I forget the old places: the Invincibles season at Highbury, watching Matt Le Tissier at The Dell. When I left London to work for The People in Manchester at the age of 20, the first game I attended was an FA Cup semi-final replay between Manchester United and Liverpool at Maine Road. United 1-0 down, then 2-1 up. It was electrifying. You don't forget that. If Everton ever get away from Goodison Park, it won't erase the memory of the night they beat Bayern Munich in the European Cup-Winners' Cup semi-final. Andy Gray battering their centre-halves, and the Munich bench banging their fists in frustration on the top of the dug-out, because they wanted their big hairy-a***d defenders to get more protection from the referee. Marvellous stuff.

The exterior of the Boleyn Ground features two fake castles, which resemble something from a theme park

Bryan Robson levels at Maine Road to put United on their way to a thrilling victory against Liverpool in 1985

Bayern Munich were bullied by Andy Gray (centre) during Everton's Cup-Winners' Cup triumph that year

The Olympics are a history of billions spent on venues that rarely get used beyond the Games. Frank, Montreal.

I can see why you may think that, Frank, although Montreal's problem was not so much the usage – Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League played at the Olympic Stadium in the immediate aftermath of the 1976 Games and were well-supported and very successful – as the fact that the stadium was poorly constructed. Bits kept falling off. It wasn't finished when the Games started and the tower and roof were not completed until 11 years later. Even now, if more than 1.2 inches of snow is due to fall in the next 24 hours, the stadium cannot be used because the roof is unsafe. Montreal Impact cancelled an MLS game there for that reason as recently as March 2014. And while it was a poor venue for baseball, Montreal Expos gates were not bad at the start. I agree that, now, is it underused. No anchor tenant since 2004. But Montreal's problems were that costs doubled due to an over-ambitious design, and the structural quality of the stadium was poor. It did get the use, initially.

West Ham will only get 54,000 if the away end holds 20,000. West Ham are a very small club in comparison to Chelsea, Tottenham and Arsenal in London. Peterhouse1997, Cambridge University.

I don't object to my taxes paying for public works, but I do object to them paying for your education, if this is an example of the Cambridge brains trust. Barnet are a very small club by comparison to the three you mention. Leyton Orient, too. West Ham are smaller, that's all. Certainly than Arsenal and, to a lesser extent, Tottenham. As for Chelsea, their super club status is recent. Before, there wasn't very much in it. Indeed, had Roman Abramovich come to east London, West Ham would be a bigger club than Chelsea right now; the same applies had he bought Tottenham. Chelsea are expanding quickly now, obviously, but I've seen them relegated at Stamford Bridge and West Ham often drew more, even in the early days of the Premier League. For instance, 1994 – when Chelsea's average attendance was 19,416 and West Ham's was 20,572; or 1992, when Chelsea got 18,686 and West Ham 21,342. Go back to 1987 when Chelsea drew 17,694 in the old Division One and West Ham 20,608. And in the years when Chelsea were out of the top division, and West Ham were not, crowds at Upton Park were often double. In 1983, Chelsea averaged 12,672 and West Ham 22,822 – a year earlier Chelsea's average was 13,132 and West Ham's 26,585. I doubt very much if you are on for a first mate. Do they give fourths at your place?

Karren Brady is very good at self-publicity. But which other football club could have moved into this stadium, taking into account geographical and financial factors? West Ham are the only one with a fan base situated near to the stadium, with enough supporters and cash. She cannot say they were cleverer than the other clubs as none of them could have capitalised on this opportunity like West Ham. JRGordon1000, London.

No, but they could have stayed where they were, couldn't they? And thought small.

Get in there, sell the club to the first dubious billionaire that rocks up and the porn barons are quids in. And the West Ham that we've all admired over the years will be dead. Progress? Roger Kint, Liverpool.

The West Ham that you've all patronised over the years, you mean. The West Ham that were never a threat. And did you read the part about what happens if the owners sell, and who gets the money?

Where's the legacy if Tottenham got it? WHU647580, Toronto.

The athletics legacy would have been a purpose built stadium and indoor training facilities at Crystal Palace – the home of athletics. Stratford is to athletics what the Etihad Stadium is to the England football team. Real Ale Madrid, United Kingdom.

Yes, because when we think of Jessica Ennis-Hill, Mo Farah and Greg Rutherford, we all think of Crystal Palace, don't we? The times we trekked across town to a corner of London with no tube link to watch them run there. No, fool, we think of the London Olympic Stadium. That is what changed in 2012. Athletics became synonymous with that venue, which is why we hold the Anniversary Games there each year. And athletics can continue to have its spiritual home in the arena where we won three Olympic gold medals in one night, because the West Ham tenancy kept that legacy alive.

I heard recently that if we had told Olympic officials that the stadium was to be handed to a football club after the event, we would not have won the 2012 Olympic Games. Not only did they hand it to a football club, they handed it to a second rate one, run by two of the most loathsome men in the game, Gold and Sullivan. Very disappointing. Noelw1969, Stafford.

Yes, the IOC are certainly very good at spending everybody else's money. How to explain it to them? How about this? Look, boys and girls, we paid for your three-week jamboree, we put you all up at five-star hotels, gave you chauffeurs, your own car lanes and your VIP seats and smiled politely even though we knew we were dealing with some of the biggest crooks on the planet, and you'll admit we put on one hell of a show. But now it's over and we need to do what we need to do with the stadium we built; so why don't you toddle off and bankrupt your next country? Thank you.

I think this whole Olympic Stadium business is disgusting. Arsenal have had to pay £600m to build their stadium, Tottenham and Chelsea the same. Why is it West Ham can be given this stadium? Halftime Hooch, Luton.

Oh dear, Disgusted of Luton writes. Anyway, the clue is in that phrase you used to describe the Emirates. Their stadium. It's Arsenal's ground – and they got plenty of state or local council help with Compulsory Purchase Orders, don't forget – so they keep all the revenue. Tottenham and Chelsea, too. West Ham do not own the Olympic Stadium – it will be used by the LLDC to host athletics, motor sport, World Cup rugby, cricket, pop concerts, and none of those other activities are making a contribution because, like West Ham, they are only tenants. Now West Ham have special privileges as the anchor tenant, but they give up the rights that Arsenal, Tottenham and Chelsea will use to help fund their moves and restructuring. Such as the money received from calling it the Emirates Stadium. It really shouldn't be that hard to understand.

Jessica Ennis competes in the long jump on her way to a famous victory at the Olympic Stadium

Following the unforgettable scenes of that year, the likes of Usain Bolt compete at the Anniversary Games

This stadium was part of the £9billion it cost for the 2012 Olympic Games, of which the north east got a big fat zero, but still had to pay. Waxi, Newcastle.

Yes, and I've never walked over the Gateshead Millennium Bridge, which cost £22m. Sometimes there are national projects that benefit one area. Manchester had bid for the Olympics several times, unsuccessfully. It was explained to our Olympic Committee that the Games were never going to the provinces, but if London applied we had a chance. Sorry, but that's the way it was. To digress slightly, during the first Kevin Keegan era I was in Newcastle quite a lot. A few of us would stay at the Copthorne Hotel on the quay. Every time we booked a taxi to the ground, the concierge gave the same advice. 'Big game tonight,' he'd say. 'I wouldn't leave it any later than six.' So we left at six. And at 6.03pm, we'd pull up outside St James' Park. And do you know what that told me? That you lot haven't a clue what real traffic is like. My point being that there are some benefits of living in Newcastle, such as cheaper housing and traffic jams that wouldn't cause mild cursing in Barkingside High Street, and while Londoners may pay the national debt of Belgium to live in a house the size of a crate, and sit drumming their fingers in traffic for two hours for no apparent reason, we get to host the Olympics because we're the capital city. But you can all come, if you wish, and you can all watch it on television, if you don't. Yes, in an ideal world, it would have been a nationally hosted event with benefits for all. But the IOC don't want to leave Park Lane and that's not London's fault. But at least some people see the bigger picture.

It makes complete sense for a successful club to take over the stadium so that it can still be used for other purposes, too. Otherwise it would end up going to waste like so many other Olympic venues. It's the benefit of being based in London. Liverpool or Everton would love the opportunity to take on something like this. Jenna McKenna-May, Liverpool.

Exactly, Jenna. It's a geographical advantage – although I did think there was one opportunity on Merseyside, now gone. You probably won't agree, but I have always thought it really unfortunate that the ground-sharing issue between Liverpool and Everton could never be resolved. Don't get me wrong, I understand club identities and respect that fans want to keep their independence above all, but one fabulous venue, an Allianz Arena, on Stanley Park, glowing red when Liverpool play, blue for Everton, as happens in Munich… Ah well. Still, while we're on the subject…

AC Milan and Inter Milan hate each other with a passion that is far beyond any English rivalry, yet they've shared a ground for 68 years. Likewise Roma and Lazio for over 50 years. Juventus and Torino also shared for most of their histories. So why can't English clubs save themselves a fortune and do the same? DrAds, Jersey.

Yes, but Juventus have now broken away and Roma will do soon, and one of the reasons is they do not like being tenants and wish to keep all of the revenue from their stadium. I suppose every club wants its own distinct character. People from outside Merseyside are more inclined to advocate sharing for Liverpool and Everton because, in recent years, both clubs have been looking for ways to expand and Stanley Park is in such proximity to Anfield and Goodison Park, but I can understand why the fans wouldn't welcome it. Chelsea are out of Stamford Bridge for three years and if they wanted to use the Olympic Stadium, I think West Ham's owners could be persuaded. But I don't think the supporters of either club would be happy. I feel your argument is built on a false premise that Italian rivalries are felt more strongly than English ones.

A soulless concrete bowl with pretty lights will never be for me. But it's all about money now. Forget history and tradition. Despite many bad memories at Upton Park, the good ones are tremendous. There is no better place under the floodlights and it will be a sad day when we leave. Denzel78, London.

Yes and it would have been a sadder one had the owners sat idle while every other major club in London – Arsenal, Tottenham, Chelsea – expanded until one day West Ham fans woke up and the club was the size of Queens Park Rangers. Actually, scratch that, even QPR are talking about moving to a bigger ground than Loftus Road.

Upton Park on match day has an incredible atmosphere. This won't compete. Outinthesticks, Chelmsford.

Yes. That's why they have won so many trophies there.

AC Milan and Inter Milan have shared the Stadio Giuseppe Meazza - the San Siro - for almost seven decades

Frank McAvennie's diving header helped West Ham beat Watford at a lively Upton Park in November 1985

Let's have transparency and the full facts revealed by the Freedom of Information request. Let us all be assured that the deal is not only legal but ethically fair and acceptable in the current climate. David Todman, Portsmouth.
