As was explained, many of the redacted figures in the deal are to allow the LLDC to negotiate aggressively with other users. If every last penny of West Ham's arrangement was made public the LLDC would have no bargaining position. Bidding for Premier League football is blind because that forces the price up. If it wasn't, the second bidder could just offer 1p more than the first.

So many bitter Tottenham fans on here. Maybe it's the view from Milton Keynes they don't like. Can you see the Olympic Stadium from there? Tommy, London.

Usually, this debate has no truck with tribal postings. But as it finds it rather amusing that master negotiator Daniel Levy must pack up for Milton Keynes because, somehow, he has failed to secure a temporary home in London for an event he knew was coming, I'll let that one slide.

Baroness Brady is clearly an excellent businesswoman and negotiator but loves to get herself on camera. Say what you like about Abramovich, the Glazers and whoever actually owns Arsenal, at least they keep themselves out of the limelight. Stevethevillafan, Birmingham.

Yes, and everyone complains that you never hear from them and they are completely remote and unapproachable. The owner of Arsenal – the man you couldn't name – is known as 'Silent' Stan Kroenke. They don't mean it as a compliment. One could argue that on occasions the owners of West Ham overshare, but if that is their worst trait, it's not a bad one. Take David Sullivan's comments about Charlie Austin last week. Was it wise? No. Could it come back to haunt him? Most certainly. If West Ham ever come up against Austin in the future, he certainly won't need much motivating. But every West Ham fan was asking why they weren't bidding for Austin, and now they know. Would Arsenal's fans like to hear from Kroenke right now on the absence of major signings this summer? I'd say yes.

To me, it is great to have another potential rival to upset the established elite. Mike, Perth.

I feel the same way, Mike. I want every club to grow and invest because that improves the competition. I hate caps on ambition, such as Financial Fair Play.

Thank goodness the taxpayers of Boston and the state of Massachusetts didn't fall for the Olympic fantasy, which more often than not results in expensive, empty venues. The people get stuck with the bills while consultants and construction companies reap the rewards. PM61, Boston.

I think these are worrying times for the Olympic movement, when you consider the bidding process for the Winter Games in 2022. Only dubious regimes, China and Azerbaijan, were interested. The Games are becoming too costly for western democracies. The World Cup is going the same way.

It is a wonderful stadium, but not for football. Most fans will need binoculars to see who's on the ball. Ankyp4nky, Northampton.

The way West Ham are playing right now, mate, my guess would be the opposition.

It is a concrete bowl, the least impressive Olympic stadium in living memory, and was built as the budget games. The legacy of the Olympics is the medals won and the children inspired, not plastic seats and concrete pillars. It should have gone to the bid which cost least, Tottenham buying the land outright, as every taxpayer is now subsidising West Ham and what supporter of another club would want that? Steven, Liverpool.

You are right about the budget aspect. One of the reasons the conversion costs are enormous is that so much of the original structure was temporary. West Ham wouldn't have entertained it in that state and nor, I'm sure, would the organisers of the Rugby World Cup.

If West Ham saw the stadium's potential they should have paid what it was worth to them. Instead they exploited the fact no-one else wanted it so they could get it on the cheap. Carroll, Manchester.

No, don't all rush at once, I've got this one. So what you are saying is that if you saw a house that was derelict and nobody wanted to buy it on the market for £200,000, but you knew that it had exceptional features and potential that could be realised with investment and would sell for, say, £1m, you wouldn't pay the asking price – or even try to knock it down as you were the sole bidder? 'No,' you'd say, 'if I spent £400,000 on this house it could be worth £1m. So here's a cheque for £600,000 and we'll hear no more of it.' I take it you're not in business.

So West Ham are basically squatters? Sounds about right. Neil Carson, Belfast.

Not all squatters are bad mate. This lot were squatters.

I'd love to see the Deeds of Sale for Ascot and Goodwood. My rudimentary checks suggest both remain in British ownership, albeit with huge Middle Eastern sponsorship of certain meetings. No doubt The Queen and Lord Richmond will confirm the divestments if indeed the sales went through. Rtj1211, London.

Fair point and apologies. Blame me, because I may have misunderstood the point Karren was making. I am told, however, that if you had gone to Goodwood this year, you would have thought the place was owned by the Qataris. And that the members were not happy with the changes.

However much Conservative peer Brady tries to portray the negotiations as a David and Goliath confrontation, it clearly never was. West Ham have benefited greatly from her government connections and good luck to them. The reality is football fills stadiums, athletics doesn't and that should have been central to the planning and construction of the stadium. Manchester City Council have a great deal, and a fantastically beneficial working relationship with Manchester City, all of which was in place before any work commenced on the City of Manchester Stadium. If London and the people involved in the Olympics had put personal interests to one side and looked at how Manchester dealt with the long term legacy of the Commonwealth Games they would have secured a far better deal for the taxpayers. Boz59, Manchester.

Very true, Boz, although Manchester City's deal attracted criticism at the time, not least because Howard Bernstein, the council's chief executive, is known to be a big City fan. He was also a member of the Olympic Delivery Authority, by the way, and I'm sure would have advocated a football legacy.

Upton Park represents a piece of football history and not just English football history. They are just going to tear it down? Sad. Zacc Xav, Colombia.

It was a football ground. Some good stuff happened there, some bad stuff too, and a lot of days long forgotten. Having never been champions, the greatest moments in West Ham's history mostly took place elsewhere, not least at Wembley Stadium.

The Daily Mail conveniently forgets the stadium was built and costed as a temporary structure for dismantling at the end of the Olympics. Jimb366, Beckenham.

Yes, and what spiffing value that would have been.

No, not a running track. Can't they hide it at least? Splat444, United Kingdom.

They will. Artificial turf and the dug outs will sit on top when football is played.

West Ham should be in East Ham at Upton Park supporting local traders. Now they've moved to Stratford next to Westfield's shopping centre and to a stadium that is pretty bland and non-traditional. Pink Panther, Durham.

I don't know if you have walked down Green Street lately, mate, but I'd say the local independent traders and the local football club have very different clienteles. Unless the lads in the Bobby Moore Stand have started wearing saris.

West Ham will never fill 54,000 and now the club are talking about increasing it to 66,000. Who is going to finance these extra seats? Joe Public again. Dodger, United Kingdom.

No, West Ham.

There is a reason why other football clubs have not raised official objections to West Ham moving to Stratford. As businesses, they know that every rule was followed and scrutinised during the bidding process. Deegee, London.

Although if it takes off, I wouldn't put it past a few of them having a last minute scream up.

This deal is like going into an estate agent and saying: 'I like this four bedroom house, but before I rent it I want the owner to make it six bedrooms and add a conservatory. When that's done, I'm only going to pay you £1,000 a month instead of the £3,000 a month you could get and then I want the owner to give me £1,100 a month towards my bills while I get to keep all the wages. Oh, and they can come and cook my meals for me too. As an extra, they can come and host a BBQ here in the summer when I'm away for two weeks. Deal?' Rob, Brentwood.

No, it's not like that. Not in any way is it like that. Who was willing to pay three times West Ham's rent and hand over all the benefits? You're talking twaddle.

The Olympic Stadium is currently being prepared to host games for the upcoming Rugby World Cup

I would love to go to more matches but simply cannot afford it. This game was meant for the working class person, but it's simply not now. The footballers get richer, and play with no passion or pride. This stadium should have been used for the junior leagues, and split it in two. We paid for it, let our youngsters use it. Mamadi, Sandwell.

Firstly, one of the benefits of West Ham having the stadium is affordable tickets. Secondly – are you serious.

'What's that over there?'

'It's the Olympic Stadium, mate. It holds 54,000 people.'

'And who is playing there right now?'

'Newham Under 12s.'

I think Sullivan, Gold and Brady only took over the club with the Olympic Stadium strongly as their ultimate goal. As a long-standing West Ham fan with many memories of Upton Park, that will always be our home. The choice of either a compact history and memory-filled homely ground in the centre of the community or a cookie-cutter multi-purpose soulless venue to me is a no-brainer. Personally, it breaks my heart to see this move. Davey C, North Vancouver.

Yes, Dave, but you live in Canada. So it's really not your concern anymore. If we want an opinion on where the Whitecaps should play, we'll be in touch.

These three parasites had this already planned when they ran Birmingham. TNinfiniti, Newcastle.

Well, that certainly makes sense. Sullivan and Gold bought Birmingham City in 1993, Olympics awarded to London in 2005. That's one hell of a long game they were playing. Equally, buying a club that was £120m in debt in January 2010, when football clubs weren't even entertained as part of the Olympic legacy process until May 2010. Anyway, fair play to them if they did see it coming. They still had to become the preferred owners or tenants. It was still a gamble.

Football club on benefits – a Channel 5 documentary on the way. This is the same embarrassing, silly little club that kicked out Bobby Moore for not having a ticket. Crabstix, United Kingdom.

You can hardly hold the current owners responsible for that. David Sullivan, as the proprietor of Sport newspapers, was one of the few people to give Moore a job. It was more than the Football Association, or any major club in the country, did.

Thank you, West Ham, for saving this wonderful stadium. British athletics will now benefit for the next century and have the world class venue it has been missing. Everyone wins including the local population and the taxpayer who will turn a profit instead of all the money spent on the Olympics going to waste. The only people complaining are fans of other football teams. William Jones, England.

Athletics gets its major stadium for one month each year. In 2017, that month will be used to host the IAAF World Championships – without doubt there is benefit to other sports from West Ham's tenancy. It's not just about football. And now, a small change of pace.

I don't think sacking Sam Allardyce was a good idea. These clubs never learn. I bet Blackburn and Newcastle wished they had stuck with him now. Say what you want but he keeps teams up. West Ham played some decent stuff under him, too, as did Bolton – and he gets results. West Ham would never have lost 4-3 to Bournemouth under Allardyce. Anyway, even if they did play hoof ball so what? Manchester United have spent £300m and play boring football and but the Daily Mail can't get enough of Louis van Gaal. I'd rather have Allardyce than Roy Hodgson as England manager as well. Star Lord, London.

We get it – you like Sam Allardyce. Now for the alternate view…

Watching paint dry comes to mind. One of the main reasons our national squad is so poor, is managers like Allardyce, Mick McCarthy and Tony Pulis with their seventies brand of football. Physical, long ball, break a player's leg if he gets past you. I welcome Eddie Howe at Bournemouth and Garry Monk at Swansea trying to take the game into the 21st century. I include Slaven Bilic in that statement as his teams are physically strong but also play some nice stuff. Welcome1andall, Bedford.

I'm a West Ham fan and I stuck by Allardyce but his form in the last five months was shocking. It was clear he needed to leave, take a break and will come back strong. The club no doubt saw this but it would have been stupid to sack him before the end of last season. In the end, that bad run of games made him toxic. JFK, Hornchurch.

Seeing Sam slumped in his chair chewing gum and looking totally defeated is the image that has stuck with me from last season. He'd had enough and needed a break. Compare him to the Allardyce that appeared on Sky and Match of the Day over the weekend and it's a different man. He's rejuvenated. And by the way, he wasn't sacked. His contract expired and was not renewed. Andy H, Essex.

Whether Bilic's appointment works out is another matter, it is not secret that West Ham lost their first choice, Rafa Benitez, to Real Madrid, and that David Moyes did not want to return from Spain just yet. As far as Allardyce goes, I just think the relationship had run its course. He needed a break, they needed a fresh approach. And JFK is right about the last months of the season. West Ham won twice in the league after January 18, both 1-0 wins, at home to Sunderland and Burnley. And one point to make to the gentleman from Bedford. Tony Pulis's teams do not play bad football, and Mick McCarthy's certainly do not. Mick has always been an ambitious coach, ever since his Millwall team outplayed George Graham's Arsenal many years ago.

Slaven Bilic's reign got off to the perfect start but the Hammers have suffered two disappointing results since

Rafa Benitez was West Ham's first choice to replace Allardyce, but he returned to Spain to coach Real Madrid

What happens if they get relegated? Total farce. John, Deal.

Actually, history indicates relegation doesn't make much difference to West Ham's attendance. They lost 2,561 fans the last time and 3,265 the time before that. In 1991, they attracted more fans in the second tier than they did in the first the following season.

If West Ham is just a tenant why can't Spurs negotiate a one-year tenancy with the LLDC, playing on alternates dates to West Ham, rather than moving to the smaller Stadium MK, 52 miles out of town? There's probably a reasonable explanation – but I'd like to hear it. Walid El-Saleh, Australia.

A straightforward explanation, certainly. As anchor tenants West Ham can veto any usage that could negatively affect their business. So if the LLDC wanted to hold a monster truck rally on the pitch the night before a fixture against Manchester United, the club could, very reasonably, say no. West Ham would want at least a year, maybe two, as the sole football tenants at the stadium to establish their identity. I think that's fair, but it means their available dates do not fit into Tottenham's calendar. Chelsea, if they cannot secure Wembley, would appear more realistic partners.

Shall go out and buy myself a nice little black number and wait for the Women and Kids Free adverts. NCN Team JA, London.

You sound like you're just looking for an excuse, mate.

As a taxpayer, I get punished for others mistakes and for corporate fat cats feeding off me and other hard working British citizens. This pile yields no financial benefit or interest to either me or my family. Why should I and others have to contribute for another iconic piece of junk? I would rather pay an outright fee to fill this big hole with concrete and be done with it. Football clubs, businesses and any others using the stadium should incur the entire cost. Once again, another fine example of British people being robbed of their hard earnings left, right and centre. Andy Odysseos, London.

Right, so we all pay just for what we use, yes? So I can pull out of your family's education, local radio stations beyond London and all public works that are not in my area or do not fit my narrow range of interests; or are you going to grow up and realise that this is not how a nation works? Our taxes fund millions of projects and benefits, some of which we use, some we don't. Your cliched rant against the corporate fat cats is thinly disguised selfishness.

So Leyton Orient would not have been interested, given the same deal West Ham secured? Tell that to a dead donkey and it will get up and kick you. Tottenham were always known to be interested in moving to the stadium but were never offered the luxury of the unbelievable contract West Ham got. Wonder why? Blueandproud, Manchester.

rank_3.title: 400k fewer are doing sports after London's 2012 Olympic Games
rank_3.text:
The billions of pounds spent on the London Olympics was promised to create a legacy of sporting activity for the nation.

But the latest figures show that participation in grassroots sports each week is plummeting.

The number of people aged 16 and above taking part in sport at least once a week has slumped by 400,000 since 2012, according to figures highlighted by the Local Government Association.

They show that, in 2014-2015, 15.5million took part in sport in England, down from 15.9million in 2011-12.

Vast amounts of public money were spent on the Olympics. The initial cost of the 2012 games spiralled upwards from an initial estimate of £2.4billion in 2005, reaching an estimated £8.8billion by the close of the games

Of the 46 sports assessed, only six – athletics, cycling, netball, table tennis, archery and fencing – have shown a significant rise in participation.

Councils warn a 'couch potato' culture is worsening our obesity crisis. Ian Stephens, from the LGA, which represents councils, said: 'We are in the midst of a full-blown obesity crisis which is being exacerbated by plunging levels of grassroots sports participation. This is creating a lost generation of obese kids and putting the NHS under enormous pressure.'

The huge cost of 'couch potato' culture is highlighted by figures that show 135 diabetes sufferers have a leg, foot or toe amputated each week, with four in five of these amputations preventable. It is estimated that obesity costs the NHS £4.2billion a year and physical inactivity about £1.1billion.

Vast amounts of public money were spent on the Olympics. The initial cost of the 2012 games spiralled upwards from an initial estimate of £2.4billion in 2005, reaching an estimated £8.8billion by the close of the games.

In 2008, then-Olympics minister Tessa Jowell said the aims of the games were to 'get more people active' and 'inspire young people through sport'.

She recently admitted that the 'legacy' of the games had not worked. She told Radio 4's Today programme: 'My particular concern is that the second legacy promise was to transform a generation of young people through sport.

'Actually, children in school now are playing less sport than they were in 2009. That's why it is a wasted opportunity.'

The number of people aged 16 and above taking part in sport at least once a week has slumped by 400,000 since 2012, according to figures highlighted by the Local Government Association

In 2008, then-Olympics minister Tessa Jowell said the aims of the games were to 'get more people active' and 'inspire young people through sport'

The Conservative Government promised a strategy to increase participation, the results of which are expected in the coming months.

Last month sports minister Tracey Crouch said: 'A significant amount of public funding has been invested in sport in the last decade but the results simply aren't good enough. The recent downward trend in participation has demonstrated that the current approach has had its day.'

Swimming is still the most popular sport – with 2.5million taking part each week – but 390,700 fewer went swimming in the past year. The number of swimmers has dropped by 729,000 in the past decade.

Sport England has a £500million budget to boost sports participation between 2013 and 2017.

A spokesman for Sport England said that since 2005, when the 2012 games were awarded to London, participation has gone up from 14million taking part in sport to the current level of 15.5million.

Not everyone has backed the drive for increased participation in sport. Professor Allyson Pollock, of Queen Mary University of London, warned in the British Medical Journal that high levels of school rugby-related injuries were a cause for concern – with 12 per cent of rugby-playing pupils suffering injuries that mean they could not play for seven days.

rank_25.title: Tom Burgess aiming for London rugby league 'legacy' after New Zealand clash
rank_25.text:
Tom Burgess believes playing in the Olympic Stadium gives rugby league a chance to create a legacy in London and he hopes he can inspire the next generation as the athletes did on the same ground in 2012.

England will become the first rugby league team to play in the iconic stadium when they take on number one ranked New Zealand on Saturday.

The home side lead the three-match series 1-0 after a brilliant 26-12 comeback victory last weekend in Hull and with 24 hours to go until the next Test 45,000 tickets have already been sold.

England's Tom Burgess applauds the fans in Hull after a brilliant 26-12 comeback victory against New Zealand

Prop Tom Burgess practises contact in training ahead of facing New Zealand at the Olympic stadium

Burgess attempts to retain possession for England under the challenge from New Zealand's defence

And Burgess says they are ready to clinch the series in London, putting on a show for the southern fans at the same time.

‘The turf is hallowed with the amount of stars that were there in 2012 so to be walking through the same changing rooms and tunnels as they walked through is going to be a great experience. I can’t wait,’ said Burgess.

‘I love that word, legacy. It is probably one of the main things as a sports player.

‘You get trophies and things like that but if you can leave a legacy that is probably the biggest thing you can do.

‘To think that you could inspire someone to play league in the South by putting on a good show this weekend is amazing. It shows what the main focus is about.

‘I loved watching the Olympics and I remember seeing Mo Farah and Jess Ennis win. It was unbelievable. Yorkshire got a lot of medals too!

The England squad celebrate a try during their 26-12 comeback victory last weekend in Hull

‘There will be a lot of southerners there and hopefully it is a chance to spread the game around the country – it can only be good for rugby league.’

With 65 per cent of tickets sold to fans with London and South East postcodes this weekend is a chance to show that league is not just a northern sport.

And coach Steve McNamara agreed with Burgess – saying he felt the Olympic legacy close to home so knows the importance of this fixture.

The England squad prepare to take on New Zealand at the Olympic Stadium in Stratford on Saturday

Steve McNamara says 'playing in the Olympic Stadium excites everyone, the players, the staff, everyone'

‘My daughter was not really fully engrossed in sport at that stage but I remember my wife ringing me and saying “you won’t believe this. Grace has got up at eight o’clock in the morning, put the Olympics on and sat there 12 hours a day watching it.”’

‘You here these stories about inspiring a generation and that was it for her – she joined a rowing club and is a rower now. That was my overriding memory from the Olympics.

‘Playing in the Olympic Stadium excites everyone, that’s the players, the staff, everyone.

‘It looks pretty sensational in terms of how they have transformed it from an athletics arena to a multi-purpose ground. We want to top the occasion off with a really good performance and a win.’

The Olympic Stadium in east London, Statford, will host England versus world No 1 side New Zealand

And with the series there for the taking Burgess knows England will have to be ready for battle.

‘We know that New Zealand will want to make amends so we have to keep improving our game,’ he added.

‘Their main asset is physicality. But they have good footwork as well as size which can be hard to handle. They have got some very talented players across the park.’

With Tom's brother Sam returning to the sport the England boys will be hoping to ride the wave of appreciation for their game come Saturday afternoon.

Sam Burgess, in World Cup action for England in 2013, has announced his return to play rugby league

rank_2.title: Olympic legacy building project in London slammed by architects over 'boring' buildings
rank_2.text:
Architects have slammed plans for a £1.3billion Olympic legacy cultural quarter because the buildings are boring 'great lumps' that don't belong in an already 'bleak' area.

The project, dubbed Olympicopolis, includes a new campus for the London College of Fashion, the V&A East, and Sadler's Wells in Statford, near the Olympic Stadium.

The brand new cultural quarter was supposed to be an inspiring vision that would complete the Olympic legacy, bringing culture and thousands of jobs to East London.

Architects have slammed plans for a £1.3billion Olympic legacy cultural quarter (pictured, artist's impression) because the buildings are boring 'great lumps' that don't belong in an already 'bleak' area

The park would include the V&A East, which would house exhibitions on the waterfront in Startford

There would also be a 550-seat theatre at Sadler's Wells, near the Olympic Aquatics Centre in East London

The London College of Fashion campus (pictured, artist's impression) will accommodate 6,000 new students

But leading architects has criticised the project, describing the uninteresting buildings as characterless warehouses that may end up as useless white elephants

But leading figures within culture have criticised the project, describing the uninteresting buildings as characterless warehouses that may end up as useless white elephants.

Sir Simon Jenkins, former chairman of the National Trust, said: 'The area is just so bleak that the last thing it needs are these great warehouses,' reports The Times.

He added: The sadness of these legacy sites is that we always end up with huge inflexible buildings that don't relate to the street pattern of East London at all.'

Architect Ian Ritchie, from the Royal Academy of Arts, said: 'The individual buildings do not strike one as being particularly interesting, nor together. Somehow they are fighting each other.'

The project was dubbed Olympicopolis because it was meant to rival Albertopolis, the collection of buildings, including the Natural History Museum, in Kensington, spearheaded by Prince Albert.

But many experts claim the project, due to bring 3,000 jobs to the area of East London and a £2.8billion boost to the economy, will not compare to the quarter alongside Hyde Park.

Recent criticism is another blow for the project, due to be completed by 2021, after the Washington-based Smithsonian Institute pulled out of its plans to open its first foreign museum in the quarter.

This graphic shows the layout of where the Olympics were held and where the new project, which is supposed to be a part of the 2012 legacy, will be

The Washington-based Smithsonian Institution pulled out of its plans to open its first foreign museum in the quarter, and will instead collaborate on exhibitions with the V&A (pictured, artist's impression)

Instead it will collaborate on exhibitions with the V&A East, 60,000 ft sq, which will be half the size of what was originally proposed.

Sadler's Wells will have a 550-seater theatre for the digital age and the London College of Fashion campus will accommodate 6,000 new students.

There will also be a second campus for University College London, catering for up to 3,000 students, which will be its single largest expansion since it was founded in 1826.

The scheme will attract 1.5 million visitors a year and deliver a £2.8bn boost to the economy of Stratford, according to the London Legacy Development Corporation (LLDC).

Rosanna Lawes, Executive Director of Regeneration at theLLDC said: 'Stratford and east London are changing fast.

'In a few short years we will see not only a new cultural and education district in east London with some of the world's leading institutions sitting in the heart of the Park, but new neighbourhoods and business districts and hugely successful sporting venues delivering on the legacy promises made for the 2012 Games.

rank_1.title: The property legacy of London 2012: Four years on, what’s it like to live in the Olympic village?
rank_1.text:
Legacy is a loaded word. And Rio will be hearing it a lot during and after the 2016 Games, which begin today amid much razzmatazz in the city’s Maracana stadium.

For London, four years on, it triggers heated debate, especially in and around the Olympic Park — now rebranded the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park — where it’s sometimes hard to see the homes for the cranes.

But walking around what used to be the athletes’ village, which has become the East Village, just outside the park, is to witness a new London neighbourhood that could prove the sceptics wrong.

Success: East Village in Stratford was the athletes’ quarters for the London Games

The high rises where the likes of Mo Farah and Jessica Ennis took up temporary residence in the summer of 2012 might not be to everyone’s taste, but the 67 acres on which they sit comprise nearly 3,000 flats, with 95 per cent occupancy.

There are two landlords: Get Living London, which manages 1,439 homes that are rented out at normal market values, and Triathlon Homes, which runs the affordable housing element, which includes offering subsidised rents and a shared ownership scheme.

Get Living London’s rents (it charges no administration fees and offers residents tenancy agreements of up to three years) go from £395 per week for a one-bedroom apartment to £770 per week for a four-bedroom townhouse. Triathlon’s renters can pay less than £200 a week for a two-bedroom flat.

‘What we’ve got is a rented village and the question now is how far and quickly can we grow a sustainable community,’ says Bernadette O’Shea, of Triathlon Homes, a joint venture between the private and public sector involving two housing associations and an urban and investment company called First Base.

Olympics: Gymnast Beth Tweddle

Huge effort has been made on the community front. With the Westfield shopping centre so close, small, independent retailers have been encouraged to set up business around Victory Park. There are playgrounds and outside exercise areas; green spaces with trees and wild flower meadows, pubs and restaurants.

On Sundays, there is a regular food and arts and crafts market, and last week Beth Tweddle, GB’s bronze medal winner for gymnastics at the London Games, opened a Summer of Sport programme offering free outdoor fitness classes.

Beyond the East Village, it’s very much a case of construction work in progress.

Residents moved in earlier this year to the first building at Chobham Manor, one of five new neighbourhoods planned within the park itself.

Prices started at £375,000 for a one-bedroom flat and all Chobham’s 259 units have sold apart from one — a five-bed townhouse on the market for £1,050,000.

‘We were renting in Stoke Newington when our landlord announced he was selling up,’ says Suzanne Duffy, 44, who moved to East Village 18 months ago with her partner and two young children.

‘I was surprised that we ended up here, but we absolutely love it.

‘It’s exciting to be part of something that is evolving and having access to so many great sports facilities is wonderful.’

Suzanne’s oldest child attends the nearby Chobham Academy School, which has just been rated ‘outstanding’ by Ofsted.

Next to the school is the Sir Ludwig Guttmann Health and Wellbeing Centre, housing a doctors’ surgery, dentist and chemist, and offering a walk-in service for all kinds of health issues.

Chobham Manor eventually will provide 849 homes and in total 6,800 new homes are planned for the park over the next ten years.

What both East Village and the rest of the park share are extraordinarily good transport links. Indeed, Stratford is now second only to King’s Cross as the most connected part of the capital.

There are two Underground lines, the Docklands Light Railway, an overground train line and Stratford International (hop on here and hop off in Paris, or go seven minutes the other way to St Pancras).

Detailed plans for the so-called Olympicopolis quarter (a nod to Albertopolis, the cluster of museums and academic institutions in South Kensington) on the Stratford waterfront, featuring an off-shoot of the Victoria and Albert Museum, the London College of Fashion and Sadler’s Wells Theatre have been announced — to mixed reviews.

But it’s early days. ‘There is a real atmosphere of excitement among people who have moved here and you can already feel a sense of pride about being part of the Olympic legacy,’ says Neil Young, of developer Get Living London.

‘And when you think that a third of our residents were living with their parents before moving here, it makes you realise how we are helping to deal with the shortage of homes issue in London.’

rank_33.title: London Assembly demands West Ham's landlord's accounts
rank_33.text:
London Assembly members have demanded to see the financial accounts of the company that owns West Ham's London Stadium home amid concerns it is heading towards insolvency.

The centrepiece of the 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games is owned by E20 Stadium LLP, a joint venture between the London Legacy Development Corporation (LLDC) and Newham Council.

Despite having West Ham as an anchor tenant, the £752million stadium has been dogged by financial concerns as the price tag for converting it from an athletics venue to a football ground, and vice-versa, has repeatedly surpassed estimates.

There are fears the owners of West Ham's London Stadium are heading towards insolvency

This has led the assembly's budget and performance committee to take the rare step of issuing a summons notice for E20's 2016/17 accounts.

In a statement, the committee's chairman Gareth Bacon said: 'This company spends vast amounts of public money and we know it is in financial difficulty.

'But we have been prevented from seeing the accounts of E20 Stadium LLP. Why?

'The assembly needs this information immediately so we can assess whether (London Mayor Sadiq Khan) is making the right decisions when it comes to the London Stadium and Olympic legacy.

'The assembly needs to do its job of scrutinising the issues that matter to London, unhindered.'

London Assembly members have demanded to see the financial accounts of E20 Stadium LLP

The stadium has been dogged by financial concerns despite West Ham's tenancy

Khan announced a review into the Stratford venue last November and is scheduled to receive a much-delayed report on the matter from accountancy firm Moore Stephens by the end of this month. It is hoped that this report will be published before the end of the year.

However, assembly members, whose job it is to hold the mayor to account, are clearly losing patience and E20 now has two weeks to hand over its most recent set of annual accounts.

Earlier this month during a two-hour session at the assembly, the outgoing chief executive and new chairman of LLDC were asked to explain how the stadium's conversion bill rose by £51million in 2016 alone and what they planned to do about it.

Answers were thin on the ground, though, beyond confirming what is now widely known about the real cost of moving the stadium's temporary seating into and out of position so it can be used for athletics, concerts, football and other events.

It is understood, for example, that it cost £8million to transform West Ham's new home into the venue for this summer's World Athletics Championships and back again, instead of the original estimate of £300,000.

The cost of switching it from an athletics to a football venue has cost more than expected

It cost £8million to alter the venue for the 2017 World Athletics Championships and back again

These revelations have led some to ask if West Ham's tenancy deal, which at just £2.5million a year has been described as the 'deal of the century', should be revisited.

And there have also been reports that E20 could be placed in administration to allow the whole operation to be restructured.

An LLDC spokesperson said: 'LLDC and Newham Council are working closely with E20, the London Stadium's owners, to address the long-standing financial challenges in the best interests of the residents of Newham and Londoners.

'A decision about the future of E20 and the stadium will be made by the Mayor alongside the publication of the Moore Stephens review.'

rank_37.title: Sadiq Khan to take control of West Ham's London Stadium
rank_37.text:
London Mayor Sadiq Khan is to take over control of West Ham's London Stadium, it has been announced.

An independent review was published on Friday morning, which said there had been 'a catalogue of errors' leading to massively increased costs after the conversion from the London 2012 Olympics.

It was a 'bungled decision that has left the taxpayer to foot an annual loss of around £20 million', the review said.

The Hammers pay £2.5m a year in rent to use London Stadium for home fixtures

Sadiq Khan lamented a the errors of decision-making in transforming London Stadium

Mr Khan said: 'I ordered the review into the finances of the London Stadium to understand how key decisions were made about its transformation and why costs were allowed to spiral out of control.

'What has been presented is simply staggering. Not for the first time, it reveals a bungled decision-making process that has the previous Mayor's fingerprints all over it.'

Mr Khan ordered the investigation after it had been revealed that the bill to taxpayers for converting the centrepiece of the London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games into a multi-purpose venue had climbed to £323m.

London Legacy Development Corporation (LLDC), the body which operates the stadium for the Greater London Authority, admitted problems with the venue's retractable seating were the biggest cause of the rise in costs.

Premier League side West Ham, who have a 99-year lease on the 60,000-seat stadium, made a one-off contribution of £15m to the conversion costs and pay £2.5m a year in rent. The total price tag for the stadium, which also has a new roof, is estimated to be £752m.

Mr Khan commissioned a review by forensic accountants Moore Stephens in March 2017, and the 169-page report warned the cost to the public is never going to be recovered, while the stadium would also continue to lose up to around £20m every year.

'Boris Johnson clearly panicked when faced with legal challenges about West Ham and Newham's joint bid to take ownership of the stadium and then decided to re-run the bid process with the taxpayer taking all the risks and footing almost the whole bill. You simply couldn't make it up,' Mr Khan said.

'The fact he also failed to properly examine the transformation costs or the entirely inadequate estimates for moving the retractable seats leaves us squarely in the dire financial situation we are in.

David Sullivan (left) and David Gold (right) managed to overcome Tottenham in a bidding war

The Hammers welcomed Sadiq Khan's decision to step in and offer new lea

'I am determined to put the London Stadium towards a stronger financial footing and secure its long-term future, but I'm under no illusion that this is going to take time and some real commitment from all partners to make this work.'

West Ham issued a statement in response to the report, which said the club had 'entered a fair and competitive tender process' as they were selected as anchor tenant.

The Premier League club view the Concession Agreement signed in 2013 as 'a watertight, legally-binding contract' and remain 'absolutely committed to its terms for the entire 99-year duration'.

West Ham will 'continue to devote our absolute commitment to London Stadium' but added 'our first priority in this sense is always to act in the best interests of our supporters'.

'We fully concur that West Ham United has played a significant part in the most successful regeneration programme in the history of the modern Olympics, however the stadium itself craves renewed leadership and direction and we welcome the Mayor's decision to step in and deliver this. West Ham United is firmly behind him,' the statement concluded.

A statement said the club: 'Continue to devote absolute commitment to London Stadium'

The Moore Stephens report said the decision to transform the stadium and enter into contract with West Ham was 'made on incorrect financial estimates and an insufficient appreciation of the critical commercial and financial risks'.

The report added: 'It is our opinion that the financial estimates were incorrect not because they were estimates, but because there were errors in their calculation, compilation and presentation.'

Sources close to former London Mayor Boris Johnson, now the Foreign Secretary, rejected the criticisms.

An ally of Mr Johnson said: 'No other city has an Olympic legacy like London's - all seven venues on the park are in private hands, with millions of visitors a year, and a positive economic legacy for east London. The stadium has a secure future with athletics and football.

'The mistakes belonged to Khan's Labour predecessor Ken Livingstone and the Blair government. Signing off on a stadium fit only for athletics was a massive error. The only option for Boris was conversion to a multi-use venue.

'If Sadiq Khan wants to try and blame someone he should blame his New Labour pals and the old Labour Mayor for their catastrophic planning failures.'

rank_109.title: No Hitler analogies when Boris Johnson flew the flag for Beijing
rank_109.text:
Boris Johnson has compared Russia's World Cup to the 1936 Berlin Olympics, with Vladimir Putin glorying in the event and manipulating it to sanitise his regime as Adolf Hitler did.

Well, as a flag-waving veteran of Beijing 2008, Boris would know.

While sport continues to deliver its biggest festivals to tyrannical governments such as China, Russia and Qatar and while politicians continue to stand idly by when it suits them, the spectre of 1936 will always linger.

Boris Johnson has hit the headlines once again following his controversial World Cup remarks

A former general secretary of FIFA, Jerome Valcke - now disgraced, but aren't they all - admitted as much at a symposium five years ago.

'Less democracy is sometimes better for organising a World Cup,' said Valcke. 'When you have a very strong head of state who can decide, as maybe President Vladimir Putin can do in 2018, then that is easier for us as organisers than a country such as Germany, where you have to negotiate at different levels.'

You can pretty much guess the German leader who FIFA would have been able to rub along with - and it isn't Angela Merkel.

Johnson was the first minister to talk of boycotting Russia after Putin's regime brought chemical warfare to the streets of Salisbury, but he wasn't so outspoken 10 years ago when, as London Mayor, he was on handover duty at the Beijing Olympics.

'We have been dazzled, we have been impressed, we have been blown away by these Beijing games,' he told a press conference following a meeting with his mayoral equivalent. He added that while criticisms of China's human rights record could not be overlooked he had not raised the issue at that morning's gathering.

'I don't think you will necessarily achieve what you want in this context by showboating and grandstanding,' he said, sagely. You'd pay good money for a line like that over the West End.

Fast forward 10 years and our foreign secretary could win Mastermind with showboating and grandstanding as his specialist subject.

He knew exactly what he was doing this week, dropping 1936 into the conversation. Immediately, he conjured images of the 2018 World Cup being used by Putin much as Hitler and film-maker Leni Riefenstahl used the Berlin Games.

However, Johnson wasn't as a critical of the 2008 Beijing Olympics and the political issues

Riefenstahl's documentary, Triumph of the Will covered the 1934 party congress in Nuremberg - a beautifully directed depiction of a purely evil ideology. In 1938, she made Olympia which, while ground-breaking in technique and featuring extensive footage of Jesse Owens, was still a work commissioned for propaganda purposes by, quite literally, a bunch of Nazis. Riefenstahl was touring America promoting her film when news broke of Kristallnacht, the most significant pogrom against Germany's Jews and she was asked to leave.

Johnson is an intelligent man and knew the power of his allusion - just as he knew what he was ignoring in 2008. The opening ceremony in Beijing was as triumphant a piece of propaganda as anything Riefenstahl conjured. It was spectacular, lavish, magnificently executed, perfect to the last step, exquisitely performed.

It was also achieved with the total subjugation of the participants.

The 900 soldiers unrolling the scroll that was the centrepiece of the ceremony had to wear nappies, because they were forced to stay hidden for seven hours and not even allowed a toilet break. The three-minute umbrella dance required six months of training, for between 14 and 15 hours each day.

The young girls auditioning had to be pretty, above 1.66 metres tall and prepared to strip naked for the judges, who then measured their body proportions. Not only did Britain's political class have nothing to say about that, some even chided the sceptics.

The 1936 Olympics were used as a propaganda vehicle by Adolf Hitler for the Nazi regime

'You can get big headlines back home by slating the oppressive regime,' said Tessa Jowell, then Minister for the Olympics, 'but there is a risk of going too far.'

Not now, it would seem. Now, no analogy is beyond bounds, no standing too grand, no show too boating. So, will England boycott? Probably not, because it costs money. There is a risk if England withdrew in isolation that FIFA would impose sanctions, including suspension and financial penalties.

Exile from FIFA would not just take England out of the 2018 World Cup, but the 2019 Women's World Cup and the Under 17 and Under 20 World Cups, in which England are defending champions, due to take place next year.

Suspension from FIFA could also exclude England from UEFA qualification from the 2020 European Championship, the final stages of which are to be held at Wembley, plus the World Cup in 2022.

Where this would leave English clubs in European competition is also unknown. It could be that English suspension is limited to the national team, but UEFA club tournaments are also, strictly, under FIFA's remit.

There would be hundreds of millions at stake were England forced out of the Champions League.

That is after FIFA starts hitting the FA for liability costs regarding loss of revenue from commercial agreements.

An automatic fine of £190,000 would be nowhere near the half of it. Participation revenue alone amounts to £6.8m - and once FIFA have been paid out, the FA would need to address penalty clauses in their own sponsorship deals with Vauxhall, Nike and other commercial partners.

Tensions are high between Vladimir Putin's Russia and Britain after a spy was poisoned

Their only, faint, hope of avoiding a catastrophe would be if they could persuade FIFA that a boycott was not a boycott at all, but a safety measure following advice from the Foreign Office.

If the FA were told that players and officials might be endangered, or that supporters were not safe, they could argue they had no option but to withdraw.

The decision would, in those circumstances, not be political, but human. If fans faced harm following the team, better for the team not to travel. The problem is, the government might still want their boycott headlines.

A grand, government-led gesture of defiance would play a lot better than an England team frightened to leave its own shores, under orders from civil servants. Can't see Johnson fronting up beneath that banner for the cameras.

Meanwhile, on September 30, 10 teams - seven based in Britain - will contest the Russian Grand Prix in Sochi, watched by Putin from his personal box, this being his pet project. No mention of that from any politicians yet and no talk of boycotts.

Maybe Johnson believes on this one, as in China, nothing will be achieved by showboating and grandstanding; not unless more showboating and grandstanding is precisely his aim.

Jack blow is timely warning

It is terribly unfortunate that Jack Wilshere failed to make the plane to Amsterdam on Thursday, but also timely.

Like seeing Daniel Sturridge leave the field after three minutes for West Brom against Chelsea, or that occasion when Gareth Southgate travelled south specifically to watch Andy Carroll for West Ham, only for him to pull out of the game with a groin injury on the day, it is a reminder.

Tournaments are tough and intense and if a player is injury-prone he has to be a game-changer to be risked.

Sadly, as talented as Wilshere is, he has not played enough football to be considered that for England. Southgate cannot build his midfield around a potential no-show.

Jack Wilshere, pictured in training on Thursday, did not travel with England to Holland

Sanchez has to prove he is United class

Alexis Sanchez was a big fish in a small pool at Arsenal. They are an elite club, yes, but Sanchez was far and away their best player. Meaning, when things did not go well, he could act the victim.

Hands on hips, or thrown in the air in frustration - the universal sign language for being surrounded by incompetents. It is harder to swing that at Manchester United. Now, Sanchez's team-mates are players who would walk into Arsenal's team: Marcus Rashford, Romelu Lukaku, Juan Mata, Paul Pogba, Jesse Lingard, Anthony Martial, Nemanja Matic, even Marouane Fellaini.

It may be a team in transition, as Jose Mourinho claims, but it is not one in which Sanchez can bemoan his misfortune or the shortcomings of others. He needs to prove himself a Manchester United player.

Alexis Sanchez has been underwhelming since joining Manchester United from Arsenal

Sanchez admits he has come up short so far, but offers mitigation. 'The change of clubs was something that was very abrupt,' he says. Except it wasn't.

There was speculation about Sanchez leaving Arsenal for several years. He will have been aware of that and played like a man who was on his way for much of this season.

It is unthinkable that he was not kept abreast of developments by his agent, Fernando Felicevich, or that interested clubs did not sound out his representative over fees and personal terms. Presuming that information was passed on, a January transfer cannot have been a surprise.

Equally, once the ball was rolling, the move did not happen overnight.

In November, it was known Manchester City would bid for Sanchez, amid interest from Manchester United, and the Old Trafford deal was not completed until January 22.

He had a lot of time to get his head around his transfer - even if he initially imagined he would be playing for Pep Guardiola, in blue. So he has a lot of ground to cover. He can't just stand, disgusted and persuade the world how great he could be, if only his team-mates were better.

With United's red shirt comes significant expectations. Having acted like he was too big for Arsenal, it would be an irony if Manchester United proved too big for Sanchez.

Sanchez needs to start turning in the performances that are expected of him as United player

Bentley view on 'Postman Pat' Fabio shows weakness at heart of English Game

David Bentley has been recalling his days as an England international, under Fabio Capello. He said the players did not like it when the manager banned tomato ketchup, spoke of smuggling a McDonald's takeaway in with Jimmy Bullard when under curfew and laughed about referring to Capello as 'Postman Pat' to his face.

Capello's limited English meant he wasn't in on the joke and would carry on talking, while players sniggered behind his back.

'If you are tense and overthink it, you play rigid,' Bentley concludes. 'And that's England's problem.'

No. England's problem is that, given the chance to work with a coach who has won the Champions League, five Serie A titles and two La Liga titles, who was European Coach of the Year in 1994, Serie A Coach of the Year in 2005, who has been inducted into the Hall of Fame for both Italy and AC Milan, instead of receiving information and learning, England's chuckle-headed idiots preferred to gripe about fast food and sugar-laden condiments and make stupid in-jokes.

Meaning they got their clock cleaned at the 2010 World Cup, not because they were too rigid, but because they couldn't master the basics of tactical organisation that are second nature to teams like Germany. Yes, Capello did look a bit like Postman Pat; but England too often look like a team with all the football nous of his black and white cat. And that's a lot more embarrassing.

David Bentley has spoken out about his time in the England team under ex-boss Fabio Capello

Strange that everyone seems so disappointed with Kevin Pietersen's farewell to cricket. Having been portrayed as a supreme egotist throughout his career, he modestly retired with a single tweet - 'Boots up, feet up' - after making seven for Quetta Gladiators in the Pakistan Super League in Sharjah.

It wasn't just his supporters who were left wanting more. Even his critics appeared to miss the opportunity for a lap of honour, a last hurrah and a chance to say goodbye to one of the sport's greatest players.

Yet had Pietersen gone out like John Terry did at Chelsea - a staged withdrawal from the Stamford Bridge pitch in the 26th minute, milking every last moment, not a dry eye in the house - he would have been slaughtered, as Terry was. There really is no pleasing some people.

Make Hammers feel at home or lose legacy of London 2012

Drip by drip, the truth is emerging about the London Stadium, the incompetence, the cost and the reality of Britain's Olympic legacy. The London Assembly budget monitoring committee heard this week that mistakes were made around the installation of the retractable seats.

'There is no suggestion we were negligent, but clearly we did get it wrong,' said David Edmonds, former chairman of the London Legacy Development Corporation. The cost of this not at all negligent mistake? Roughly £8million annually, when the seats need to be taken out for athletics and put back for the new football season.

Neale Coleman, the LLDC's former vice-chairman, said that in retrospect the model used in Manchester after the Commonwealth Games - when the stadium was passed to Manchester City and converted for football purposes - would have been better.

The incompetence, the cost and the reality of the London Stadium legacy is ever-emerging

Thank the brains trust of Tessa Jowell, Ken Livingstone and Lord Coe for that - they were the ones who insisted on an Olympic legacy and would not entertain the idea of a solely football-driven takeover. Yet football is the only sport that could consistently fill the stadium and make it viable - and even that future is threatened with stadium operator E20 making the place so inhospitable for West Ham and its fans.

And now to the final point. Edmonds admitted that the reason West Ham got such a good financial deal on the stadium was that they were the only game in town by the time it came to negotiations. Tottenham's proposal had been rejected; Leyton Orient's interest was a myth. It was West Ham, or nothing. West Ham, or empty.

The whole process has been an utter shambles and unless E20 start to make the place feel more like home for its anchor tenants, what tiny legacy remains could be lost. The politics needs to stop and the constructive solutions need to start. This is a national scandal and the size and scale of it is only just emerging.

On recent tours, it has been discovered that England's cricketers can't play against spin bowling, can't play against fast bowling and now, apparently, can't play against swing bowling either. Unless the ECB finds a country that bowls underarm, there aren't really many places to go.

rank_18.title: More than 30,000 cyclists ride from London to Surrey and back again
rank_18.text:
Advertisement

Scores of amateur cyclists have gummed up 100 miles of road around London and the commuter belt in the annual 2012 Games legacy race.

The Prudential Ride London event - the brainchild of former Mayor Boris Johnson - saw around 30,000 people mount their bikes at the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park this morning before peddling to Surrey and back.

Supporters lined the streets of the capital to cheer the cyclists who were blessed with clear skies and hot temperatures.

But it was a grim forecast for motorists who were told to expect mammoth road closures as the event booted cars off their route which criss-crossed the city.

Drivers moaned of 'chaos' as a sea of bikes clogged up the start point in Stratford, east London, and blamed cyclists for quadrupling journey times.

One disgruntled driver tweeted: 'Absolute joke. Did you consult residents before closing a major road with no notice?

Cyclists passing through Dorking pass the town crier during The Prudential Ride London, the 2012 Olympic Games legacy event today

A cyclist in a recumbent bicycle tackles a corner at Pebble Coombe, near Headley and Box Hill, during today's ride

Supporters lined the streets of the capital to cheer the cyclists who were blessed with clear skies and hot temperatures

A horde of cyclists clad in lycra race down the Mall as 30,000 people mounted their bikes at the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park this morning

A number of celebrities took part in the Prudential Ride London event including singer Lemar (left) and Labour's deputy leader Tom Watson (right)

'A 45-minute diversion for a 10-minute trip. Stratford was chaos. Couldn't get into Canary Wharf. The roads are for everyone, not just for cyclists!'

Some 100 miles worth of tarmac has been closed as cyclists take on three separate routes of 100, 46 and 19 miles long.

Footballer David Seaman, singer Lemar, Love Island star Laura Crane and deputy Labour leader Tom Watson were among the famous faces on the course today.

And England's 2003 Rugby World Cup-winning captain Martin Johnson reportedly looked exhausted as he crossed the finish line earlier.

The sportsman, who completed the 100-mile course in four hours and 42 minutes said: 'I went out too fast over the first 20 miles and thought "oh, this is going to be hard" - and it was! It was still enjoyable, though - it always is.'

A professional race of around 160 competitive riders was held alongside the amateur event. They did several laps of Box Hill in Surrey before zooming back to the Mall in central London.

Yet the supposed spectator event was slammed by fans who moaned that road closures prevented them from getting to the route.

One disappointed spectator tweeted: 'What a complete mess this year's event is. Ruined all the good viewing points in Dorking and how are people supposed to go and watch the laps around Box Hill when the roads have been closed since 5am? A joke.'

The Prudential Ride London event - the brainchild of former Mayor Boris Johnson - saw around 30,000 people mount their bikes at the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park this morning before peddling to Surrey and back

Some 100 miles worth of tarmac has been closed as cyclists take on three separate routes of 100, 46 and 19 miles long

A sea of bikes snake through sprawling Richmond Park to the backdrop of the city of London during today's Prudential Ride London event

Amateur cyclists pass through Wimbledon in south west London as they peddle to Surrey before turning around and finishing on the Mall

rank_123.title: Moving Tottenham to east London would rip 'the heart and soul' out of the club's community
rank_123.text:
Moving Tottenham to east London would rip 'the heart and soul' out of the club's community



Tottenham's prospective switch to the Olympic Stadium following the 2012 Games has led to fears the move would rip 'the heart and soul' out of the club's local community.



Spurs are among those who have put themselves forward to take up the lease of the site, with a preferred bidder due to be announced later this month and a confirmed agreement drawn up by the end of March.



If Spurs are given the green light, it would see them abandon plans for a multi-million pound redevelopment of White Hart Lane, their home for 111 years, and relocate from north to east London.



Stratford Hotspur? Tottenham are vying with West Ham over the future of the Olympic Stadium

Such a possibility has outraged the MP for Tottenham, David Lammy, who has called on the Government to intervene in the naming of the preferred bidder in order to safeguard the future regeneration of his constituency.



Speaking during a debate in Westminster today, Lammy said: 'Can it possibly be fair that Tottenham's legacy from the Olympics is for the largest private employer to be allowed by this government to depart?



'The Olympics were meant to bring a unique experience to the doorsteps of ordinary Londoners.



Home: Tottenham have had plans approved to improve White Hart Lane

'In N17, that experience will have a particularly bitter aftertaste should Spurs leave as a result.



'Never did I imagine our successful Olympic bid would mean that residents of Tottenham, and those of Enfield, Waltham Forest and the whole of the Upper Lea Valley would have the heart and soul ripped out of their communities.



'What kind of an Olympic legacy would that be?'



Club officials are due to meet with Lammy and Andrew Stunell MP, the Minister for Regeneration, later this month.
